story: IM Subscribe  registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe  registerIM Join us? SubscribeJoin us? Subscribe  registerJoin us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsTSB lost thousands of customers this year due to a series of major IT failuresClick to followThe IndependentCustomers rated TSB the worst UK bank after a troubled year for the lenderTSB&nbsphas fallen to bottom place in a ranking of UK banks, while challenger Monzo rose to first place, according to consumer watchdog Which?The bank was rated worst for overall customer satisfaction in a survey of more than 4,200 people. They&nbspwere asked their opinions on their bank’s current account, and how likely they were to recommend the company. TSB’s overall score was 58 per cent, putting it in joint last place with Bank of Ireland, which was bottom of the table for the second year running. TSB sheds 20,000 current accounts in wake of massive IT failure Monzo to launch new crowdfunding round as it seeks $1bn valuationTSB boss Paul Pester steps down after new IT problemsTSB, which came in fourth in last year’s ranking, has suffered a crisis this year after a series of major IT failures, which caused&nbspthousands of customers&nbspto leave.Chief executive Paul Pester&nbspstepped down over the tech meltdown and the chaos prompted a parliamentary inquiry. More than half of the TSB customers surveyed by Which? said they had experienced technical issues in the last year. The bank also scored poorly on customer service, telephone and online banking and complaint handling. “TSB’s slump suggests that customers felt outraged to have endured the prolonged IT issues that left millions locked out of their accounts,” said Gareth Shaw, money expert at Which?A TSB spokesperson said: “We’re sorry for the problems customers experienced as a result of our IT switch.“Regrettably this is why our scores are low in this poll. Our priority is putting things right for our customers and we’ve made significant progress.”Meanwhile, Monzo came out on top after reaching a large enough sample size for the first time since it launched in 2016. The&nbsponline-only bank scored full marks for both communication and its app. With a total customer satisfaction score of 86 per cent, it narrowly beat telephone and online-only First Direct, which scored 85 per cent. Nationwide&nbspcame in third&nbspwith 79 per cent and challenger&nbsp Bank was fourth with 76 per cent. Which? said this year’s ranking showed challenger banks were gaining favour. Mr Shaw said: “Impressive results from challenger banks place them well ahead of many of the biggest banking brands in Britain, showing that innovation and modern ideas are shaking up the market, with good customer service truly valued by customers.“Our research shows a clear gap between the best and worst providers and should act as a catalyst for customers unhappy with their service to switch banks – as it’s never been easier.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - story: IM Subscribe  registerIM SubscribeCreated with Sketch.IM Join us? Subscribe  registerIM Join us? SubscribeJoin us? Subscribe  registerJoin us? SubscribeLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Try Independent Minds free for 14 daysSee the optionsEvent to champion independent retailers takes place on 1 December 2018&nbspClick to followThe IndependentShop closures jumped 17 per cent to 24,205 in the first half of the year according to the Local Data CompanySmall Business Saturday is a counterpart to the big retailers’ consumer events Black Friday and Cyber Monday that have worked their way into the UK shopping calendar over the last few years.Like its bigger brothers, Small Business Saturday is a US import, but it’s a very different affair which aims to persuade consumers to spend locally in independent shops.Think of Black Friday and the mind flashes up images of baying hordes fighting their way into&nbspdepartment stores, stripping shelves bare of cut-price flatscreen TVs.How do you grow your small business?Small Business Saturday, which is usually held on the final Saturday of November, shortly after Thanksgiving, is more sedate but offers are available.American Express, the company that helped establish&nbspthe event in 2010, is offering cardholders £5 statement credit when they spend £10 or more at participating businesses between 1 and&nbsp16&nbspDecember 2018. There is no limit on how many times the offer can be redeemed it is valid for use once per participating shop.Small retailers in the UK could certainly do with a boost as the high street reaches the end of one of its toughest years in memory, with little sign of any easing of&nbspextremely tough trading conditions.Third of small firms think pound will fall sharply after Brexit dayThis is what Facebook is doing for small businesses in the UKSmall business body calls on Hammond to address late payment ‘crisis’Shop closures jumped 17 per cent to 24,205 in the first half of the year according to the Local Data Company.The number of pubs fell 6.5 per cent in six months as people increasingly choose to buy alcohol from a supermarket and drink at home. Newsagents and clothes shops have also seen large numbers of closures thanks to falling print media sales and competition from online rivals.But research from GlobalData points to some green shoots of recovery breaking through as high streets are reshaped.It found growth in independent operators offering entertainment services like cinemas and escape rooms, hair and beauty, and health and fitness.The findings confirmed that for almost two-thirds of shoppers the desire is for experiences and opportunities&nbspto buy things that can’t be easily sourced online.Maureen Hinton, retail research director at GlobalData, said it was encouraging to see that town centres were evolving to keep up with changing shopping habits.“The growth of online has also made the high street’s role as a service-led&nbspsocial space increasingly important, encouraging the rise of hybrid businesses, with shops, gyms and cinemas now often boasting their own bars, coffee shops and restaurants.“Meanwhile, new categories of business continue to emerge, such as “experience bars”, which combine a night out&nbspwith a complete entertainment experience, centred on an activity&nbspsuch as darts, mini golf or table tennis.&nbsp“There is no doubt that the high street is in a period of unprecedented change, but the rise of new businesses such as these&nbspdemonstrates that this is as much an opportunity as a challenge.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but title: universal credit roll out delayed changes claimants
story: Leaked documents reveal Brits could get paid for an extra two weeks to stop them going into debt when going on to the new system.Millions of people were expected to start being moved over to Universal Credit from their existing benefits last year, but now they might not be put on to it until November , the BBC reported.Testing was meant to start in January, and , people each month were set to be told to move across. Now ministers are set to use the time to fix problems in the system - but the programme wont be halted or scrapped.A series of documents revealed that a whole raft of new changes could be coming to make the transition easier for Brits -they are signed off by the Treasury.It comes after a revolt by Tory backbenchers who demanded that extra cash be put in to soften the blow for Brits on benefits.Plans have been drawn up to spend hundreds of millions of pounds to continue paying some benefits to claimants for two weeks after their new Universal Credit claim has been made.Housing benefit tenants can already get this two week space, after reports of Brits going into debt at last years Budget.The documents also revealed that more help would be given to the self employed, and that the advance payments will be spread out and paid back over a longer amount of time.Labours Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Margaret Greenwood said today the news was proof that the government have quietly accepted that their flagship social security programme isnt working.She went on: The Government must stop the roll out of Universal Credit immediately. We need urgent answers from Esther McVey about whats going on and what action the Government will take to tackle the many flaws in the system.And ex-Labour MP Frank Field said the changes that could take place arent enough - and demanded benefits must continue until the new benefit is up and running into your bank account and that paying back advance payments more slowly should include other historic debts too.Dame Louise Casey said the design was flawed from the outset and it had pushed people further and further into debt because it tried to force people to be paid monthly.She told Radio : The poorest people are often paid weekly and fortnightly - those are the people we need to help... Civil servants are telling ministers this is a mess, and it needs fixing.Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently , or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Even Philippa Stroud, who used to work for the DWP, added that more money needed to be pumped in to offset cuts: Universal Credit is the right mechanism for delivering welfare, but it needs the investment restored.Campaigners including Citizens Advice welcomed the proposed moves, but said that it wouldnt solve all of the problems.Universal Credit aims to roll six benefits into one monthly payment, but the controversial new programme has been hit by a string of problems.First announced in , it was meant to be fully up and running by  - this has now been pushed back to .The new system had also been attacked for taking weeks for claimants to get their first payment, and for stopping domestic abuse victims from leaving their partners as benefits are now only paid into one account per family.Analysis from Labour revealed yesterday that Universal Credit sanctions hit Brits under  the hardest.A Department for Work and Pensions statement said today that it would be putting back the rollout.A spokesperson said: We have long said that we will take a slow and measured approach to managed migration. This will not begin in January , but later in the year, after a period of preparation.For a further year we will then begin migration working with a maximum of , people, continuing with our ‘test and learn’ approach. This is to ensure the system is working well for claimants and to make any necessary adaptions as we go.We will publish full plans for the next stage of Universal Credit rollout, including managed migration, in due course. Anything before that point is speculation and we do not comment on leaks.Claimants are able to get some cash within five days or on the same day they make a claim in emergency cases - rather than waiting weeks for their first Universal Credit payment.But the upfront payment is a loan which means youll have to pay it back.The repayments will be automatically deducted from your Universal Credit payments after youve taken the loan.You should ask for the advanceyou dont think youll have enough money to live on between when you apply and when youll get your first payment.

title: labour mp lives in social housing
story: Shadow development secretary Kate Osamor has faced intense criticism after it emerged that she promoted her son in his House of Commons job, regardless of his conviction for having £, of Class A drugs with intent to supply at Bestival in Dorset last year.Now the Sun on Sunday can reveal that Ms Osamor and her son Ishmael, , are living in social housing in Tottenham, north London - despite their earnings classing them ineligible by council guidelines.Haringey Council documents from  state that households earning in excess of £, are not eligible to apply for a social housing property.And it has been reported that , people are waiting for social housing in the borough - one of the poorest in Britain - and a further , are living in temporary accommodation due to the limited supply of properties.Ms Osamor, a close ally of Jeremy Corbyn, is paid a salary of £, plus expenses. Since being elected an MP in  she has also benefitted from £, of travel and accommodation on visits to countries including India and Nigeria.Her son Ishmael is working for her as her chief of staff and is paid up to £,. And before he resigned from Haringey council last month he was entitled to claim at least £, a year in allowances from the council.Ishmael was previously a director of two clothing companies and a second hand car sales business which was dissolved in September this year. He pleaded guilty to the drug charges on October , having brought ecstasy, cocaine, ketamine and cannabis to the music festival.Ishmael was spared prison after his barrister persuaded prosecutors he was not planning to make a profit from his £, haul of drugs.Judge Stephen Climie said the -year-old was lucky to avoid a four-year prison term and sentenced him to  hours of unpaid work instead and to pay £ prosecution costs.Osamor pleaded guilty to four drugs charges after his barrister Mohsin Zaidi struck a deal with the Crown Prosecution Service at Bournemouth Crown Court.The former Labour councillor was caught with g of ecstasy – a class A drug blamed for a string of deaths at music festivals – as well .g of cocaine, .g of ketamine and a trace of cannabis at Bestival in .Ms Osamor has denied wrongdoing in the row over her son.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jungle gentleman harry redknapp jane moore opinion
story: “I do love her too much andanything happened it would just kill me,” says the former football manager.“We just get on so well. I only want to be with her. I can never wait to see her.”Cue the nation emitting a collective swoon and ’Arry becoming odds-on favourite to take the jungle crown.“Aw, he’s sooooo lovely,” gushed one twentysomething TV commentator, asHarry had just bequeathed all his worldly possessions to help save an endangered species.Given the borderline hysterical response to this “man still loves we after  years” declaration, he might even be considered one himself.But is it really so unusual  To those dating in this Tinder-centric age where people start swiping right the second there’s a minor hiccup, perhaps. But to my generation, less so.Shortly after my Uncle Jack died in his early eighties, my Aunty Mabel announced that she wouldn’t be around for much longer because she couldn’t bear to be without him. Sure enough, she literally lost the will to live and died soon after.It was the same story with my godparents and, as a trainee reporter, I interviewed countless golden wedding coupleswho had endured all manner of marital bumps in the road but lasted the course.How many of today’s liaisons will reach that -year milestone When Harry and Sandra took their vows, they clearly both understood the now largely outdated concept that love is a decision, not just a feeling.In other words, there might have been plenty of niggles and quarrels along the waybut they pushed on through in the knowledge that reaching old age with your spouse and best friend by your side is one of le’s greatest pleasures.The shared experiences, the joy of shared memories, the private jokes, the non-awkward silences and the companionship — bliss.Interestingly, Harry and Sandra’s marital set-up is one that’s increasingly regarded as outdated in this supposedly “progressive” day and age — that of the man bringing home the bacon while the woman runs the house and does the lion’s share of parenting.Consequently, Harry, now , freely admits he can barely make a cup of tea because Sandra does everything for him.It wouldn’t be my, er, cup of tea, but it has worked for them and perhaps it’s because Harry clearly doesn’t view Sandra as “just a housewe”he sees her as the boss and someone whose input he values and respects.And therein lies the key to a happy marriage. It doesn’t matter what the dynamic is as long as each feels appreciated and respected in their chosen role.Harry is what many might consider to be an old-fashioned gentleman, when men were allowed to be one without fear of being branded patronising.He turned away from the female contestants while they were showering and, whenever he gets the chance, awards “the ladies” the rare camp comforts on offer instead of the men.A magnanimous gesture, I notice, that they all accept readily without a passing thought that it might be unfair to the male contestants in these times of supposed equality for both genders.Ashley Roberts danced her bobby socks off in the Lindy hop on Saturday’s Strictly and performed a crackingly good samba too.But she ended up in the bottom two.Why  Because the public never like what they think might be a foregone conclusion.And however much the show tries to dress her up as a plucky amateur, her previous dance experience makes it as implausible as putting Bear Grylls in the I’m A Celebrity “jungle” and seeing him scream at the sight of a cockroach.Remember that moment in Crocodile Dundee when a yob pulls a blade on Mick Dundee in New York and he responds by saying “That’s not a kne”– “that’s a kne”.Fast forward  years and consider the story of Alun Powell, of Newport, Gwent, who takes part in medieval role-playing contests as “Sir Fightalot”.A court heard that when he arrived home to find his father being plagued by a gang outside the house, he pulled a sword, axe and knuckleduster from the boot of his car and “took up a fighting stance”.The prosecution added: “They saw the weapons and got so frightened that they left as quickly as possible.”Job done. End of. Right Nope. Alun ended up in court, convicted of possessing bladed articles in public and given  hours of community service.Perhaps this is why more members of the public don’t get involved when they see trouble.Becausethey don’t have a weapon themselves, they could get hurt.Andthey do happen to have one in their house or car, and brandish it in self-defence, there’s every chance they’ll end up in court themselves while the troublemakers get away scot-free.Robert de Niro is the new face of Warburtons bread.It’s hard to choose my favourite movies starring this acting titan, but Midnight Bun would be top, followed by The Kingsmill Of Comedy and Jackie Brown Bread.Posh store Anthropologie has been ridiculed for selling a bunch of twigs for £.But is the laugh on them or the idiots who buy them In the words of the marvellous Harry Enfield, it must include “we saw you coming” tax.Following on from the debate on whether or not they should have built a ramp to rescue stranded penguins, the crew of BBC’s wildle series Dynasties are in the news again for helping a stricken lion cub.As a rule, those who film such programmes are discouraged from intervening in the events they are trying to capture on the basis that nature should be allowed to take its course.But the cub was shown collapsing and spasming after eating bait laced with poison by tribesmen who had lost their cattle to a lion a few days earlier.So perhaps the new “rule” could be that human intervention is allowed when it’s human intervention that caused the crisis in the first place So how come a -year-old Iranian man – pretending to be  – was blithely placed in a class full of GCSE pupils in Ipswich without so much as a routine dental check Education Secretary Damian Hinds has added to the curriculum certain feats he wants primary school children to achieve before they move up to secondary.He says pupils will be urged to climb trees, explore caves and watch the sun rise to help build character.A good idea, but how depressing that all the things most of us did as a matter of routine in our youth now have to be actively prescribed.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: single mum bread universal credit money
story: Joanne Davis, , whose husband left her earlier this year, has been living a “nightmare” while trying to claim for the new benefits system.The mum-of-two, who has long-term health conditions including MS, OCD and depression had waited five weeks for her benefits money to come through after making a claim - and has been threatened with eviction in the meantime.She told The Sun Online: “I couldn’t even afford a loaf of bread this week - my family had to give me money and cook for us.“It was my daughter’s birthday and I had to borrow the £ she was given.“I feel so guilty, I haven’t got another option.”Joanne, who can’t walk far because of her illnesses, had to visit her job centre several times to provide reams of proof before she got help - and had to beg for lts from family and friends to get there.Her husband previously sorted out her finances, but has now moved out of the family home leaving her and their two kids Hannah, , and Zoe, , behind.Joanne, who lives in the West Midlands, is just one of hundreds of Brits who say that going onto Universal Credit has pushed them into debt.In last month’s Budget the Chancellor announced a raft of measures to help ease their struggle - but they won’t come in for months.New DWP Secretary Amber Rudd has vowed to “fix” the problems with the flagship benefits system, which rolls six payments into one.Last week she even hinted she could slash the five-week wait to try and help those who are desperate waiting for their first payment.Joanne’s got letters and phonecalls saying she is almost £ in debt on her rent alone - and could face eviction from her houseshe doesn’t pay soon.She opted for a £ advance to help her while she waited but soon struggled with making ends meet.“I’m struggling to pay for anything including food for my girls,” she added.“I’ve been worried to death, I haven’t had anything to eat some days.“I’ve been going around to my family to get food - it makes me feel so bad.“Dad paid for us all to come over with a taxi so we could have a meal.”After waiting five weeks for her benefits to come through, she is now set to get around £, a month from UC - and her PIP disability payments are paid on top ofBut it was the “huge struggle” of waiting for it all to come through which really put a strain on the family, she said.Joanne’s former partner used to do everything beforehand for her, adding: “I never really did any shopping - or even had a bank account.”She’s slashed her bills to the minimum amount she feels is possible but still is struggling to pay the bills.“Universal Credit has been a nightmare, the benefits system should have been left how it is,” she added.“It’s caused me so much trouble and stress.”A DWP spokeswoman said: “We offer advances of up to  per cent of the first Universal Credit payment to help people who need extra support, and we’ve announced a £m partnership with Citizens Advice to support vulnerable people with their claims.“Other benefits, such as Personal Independence Payments, are available for people with mental and physical health conditions to help with additional costs.”

title: britain needs brexit leaders steve hilton opinion
story: It says: “Consider the possibility we are led by idiots.”When you look at the shambles Brexit has become, as far as Britain is concerned it’s not a possibility but a downright certainty.Let’s review the idiocy.It began with David Cameron stomping off in the biggest and most ruinous huff in history, leaving a sleep-deprived and shell-shocked Tory party scrambling to find a new leader overnight.Then Boris Johnson and Michael Gove threw away a golden opportunity as potential PM and deputy to achieve the vision of a positive, outward-looking, go-getting, post-Brexit Britain.Over a bizarre few days they stabbed each other in the back, shot themselves in the foot and indulged in whatever other self-harming metaphor you can think of.Their antics landed us with hapless and hopeless Theresa May, so desperate to prove she could deliver Brexit despite opposing it that she rushed into announcing the end-point without the faintest idea how to get there.More misguided Remainer pandering came from then-Home Secretary Amber Rudd, with her ludicrous plan to force businesses to list their foreign workers.This offensive announcement alienated Remain voters who might have given Brexit a chance and helped set in stone the horrible isiveness of the past two years.As Foreign Secretary, Boris made one gaffe after another, starting with the most heinous: Sticking to his silly remark about having your cake and eating it — guaranteed to wind up the EU bigwigs and make them even more determined to give Britain a rotten deal.On and on the idiocy has gone — from Philip Hammond trying to prove his discredited Project Fear predictions were right all along by being the most anti-businessConservative Chancellor anyone can remember, to Matt Hancock’s hysterical claims about people dying from a lack of medicineswe leave the EU without a deal. He is the Health Secretary, for God’s sake. Why doesn’t he get the medicines, instead of issuing stupid threats At least Michael Gove’s pitul descent into Project Fear ignominy, with his own Hancockian warning about running out of drinking water, turns out to be fake news — or so I’m told.And where has all this left us With a Brexit “deal” that is not really a deal and doesn’t actually deliver Brexit. The transition period leaves Britain subject to most EU rules, and there is no agreement on what comes next — just an agenda for more negotiations.How dare Mrs May say last Sunday, “The British people don’t want to spend any more time arguing about Brexit. They want a good deal that fulfils the vote” Her plan guarantees years more “arguing about Brexit” and obviously doesn’t fulfil the vote. I know politicians spin everything but this is in a dferent league. It’s not spin, Prime Minister — what you are saying is a bare-faced lie, and you know it.It is also disgraceful that the civil service is helping push out this lying propaganda at taxpayers’ expense with its Cabinet Office “Project Vote” operation.But we shouldn’t be surprised. The senior civil service has catastrophically mishandled Brexit all along, finally exposing as self-serving fiction the idea that it is the professional, reliableof the national interest, there to save the nation from the half-baked schemes of here today, gone tomorrow politicians.Yes indeed: “Consider the possibility we are led by idiots.”But now what, you might say. It’s easy to criticise — what would you do Well, I’ve said it before : Pursuing a “deal” with the EU is a waste of time. Of course you can’t stay in the single market but regain control of immigration. Of course you can’t stop paying membership fees but still set the rules. And as President Trump noted, of course you can’t strike new trade deals unless you fully leave.There is no such thing as a “soft Brexit”. There is Brexit, without adjectives — or staying in the EU in some form. “Fulfilling the vote” now requires two things: Preparing for a clean break and counteracting the inevitable short-term disruption.Disgracefully, and cynically, the Government refused to prepare for a clean break over the past two years, so now we are behind. But that doesn’t mean we can’t do it — it just means an all-out effort must be made, andnecessary the exit date pushed back.However solid the preparations, though, there is bound to be economic turbulence. But here too, we can be proactive. The Government could almost instantly make Britain the world’s top destination for business and investment.Slash corporation tax and regulations. Roll out the red carpet for entrepreneurs, scientists, investors. Commit to building the world’s most modern infrastructure and best-trained workforce.Business hates uncertainty more than anything. That is why Theresa May’s deal is a disaster — it prolongs uncertainty.A clean break and a radical pro-enterprise agenda would end uncertainty and counteract the short-term shock of departure.Once we have left, and shown how dynamic post-Brexit Britain can be, we will have much more leverage to negotiate a trade deal with the EU.Objectors will say: This is fantasy — there is no majority in Parliament for a clean break. But there is no majority for anything  either, and in any case, with a clean-break scenario the EU Withdrawal Act does not require a vote that binds the Government.But perhaps the biggest question is: Who can make this happen My idea of bringing back Cameron went down like a lead balloon. After the Rees-Mogg rebellion flopped, we are stuck with Mrs May — evenshe loses on December . No one can see a way out.There is only one answer. Pro-Brexit MPs, inside and outside Cabinet, must develop a spine, step up and unite to offer a positive alternative. Unite to get rid of TheresaMay, then make the case with passion and conviction for a clean break and a radical pro-enterprise programme.Right now, Britain needs leaders. Not idiots.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: universal credit rollout december latest
story: These are the last places the new flagship programme is coming to - and it will now will be in every job centre in the country for new claims.You only need to be aware of thisyoure making a new claim for benefits -you’re already on them then you don’t need to apply or swap unless you’re told to.Once this rollout is complete the DWP will start transferring people over onto UC starting from next year.Around , are set to be moved across first, and they will get help with making a new claim.But the new Universal Credit systems rollout has been far from smooth - with many Brits claiming its pushing them into debt.One single mum told us how she was at risk of losing her home after applying for Universal Credit - because she couldnt claim help with her mortgage debt.And yesterday another Brit said she couldnt even afford a loaf of bread while she waited for her payment to come through.There could be up to , new claims across December - the average for October, according to the DWP, was , a week.And housing association Peabody warned that , kids could get their Christmas ruined by the wait for benefits.If your Jobcentre area is not on the list then enter your postcode here to find out when it’s coming to near you.Most people will need a bank account to receive benefits - or a similar account with a credit union or building society.You need to be able to receive payments and set up direct debits and standing orders with it too.If you’re living with your partner and you’re both eligible for Universal Credit, you’ll get a joint payment - so you might want to consider a joint account too.The new Universal Credit system is mainly online, though you can get help in the job centre and over the phone too.Most Jobcentres and libraries have computers and free wi-fi you can useyou can’t get online.Andyou’re using it from home on a budget, make sure you shop around using services like U-switch to get the best internet deal too.Drawing up a budget of all your household incomes and outgoings will be helpful before you make a claim for Universal Credit.UC will be paid to you in one monthly payment for the six benefits, but in some extreme circumstances you can ask for it to be paid fortnightly or even weekly.Consider how much you get or expect to get in benefits, work and other income, and when in the month they come in to try and help you budget.And youll need to know information about your existing savings and pensions.Before you apply you should also work out your outgoings on everything from rent, food and travel, to electricity, gas, phone bills, and paying off debts.You can use a benefits calculator here to give you an estimate of what you could get.Bear in mind theres a cap on the total amount of benefits that most people can get - some benefits are included in the cap but others are not.Youll also need some form of ID to prove who you are - it can be a passport or driving licence, but they also will accept things like debit or credit cards too.Universal Credit rolls six benefits into one.If youre already on benefits, you dont need to apply for Universal Credit unless your circumstances change or youre told to by the DWP.They work it out by looking at how much you earned in the last assessment period - so anything you earn after you start a claim will count towards your income levels and could affect the amount of benefits youll get.You can earn a certain amount under Universal Credit butyou earn more than the allowances then your benefits will be reduced.Apply for an advance - Claimants are able to get some cash within five days rather than waiting weeks for their first payment. But its a loan which means the repayments will be automatically deducted from your future Universal Credit pay out.Alternative Payment Arrangements- If youre falling behind on rent, you or your landlord may be able to apply for an APA which will get your payment sent directly to your landlord. You might also be able to change your payments to get them more frequently , or you can split the paymentsyoure part of a couple.Budgeting Advance - You may be able to get help from the government to help with emergency household costs of up to £youre single, £youre part of a couple or £you have children. These are only in cases like your cooker breaking down or for help getting a job. Youll have to repay the advance through your regular Universal Credit payments. Youll still have to repay the loan, evenyou stop claiming for Universal Credit.Cut your Council Tax - You might be able to get a discount on your Council Tax or be entitled to Discretionary Housing Paymentsyour payments arent enough to cover your rent.Foodbanks - If youre really hard up and struggling to buy food and toiletries, you can find your local foodbank who will provide you with help for free. You can find your nearest one on the Trussel Trust website.Other benefits like Carers Allowance, Personal Independent Payments, and Child Benefit are still separate to Universal Credit and wont be part of your lump payment.But the income from that could affect your Universal Credit amount.You might need to book and attend an interview at your local Jobcentre before you get your first payment.Once you have successfully applied and have given all the relevant information, it will take five weeks for your first sum to come through.But you can apply for an advance  you dont feel youll be able to manage financially until that happens. The money you owe will be taken off your UC sum in future months.After youve applied you can sign in to your Universal Credit online account to report changes in circumstances, add notes to your journal, see anything you need to do, and check when your payment is coming.

title: no10 need more time to tell whether full on no deal preparation is necessary
story: This was the moment at which the principal purpose of government was meant to sht to getting this country ready for leaving the EU, regardless of whether there was deal or not.The Department For Exiting The EU wanted November  but No argued that a more vague deadline of late November  early December was better.They thought that this would give more time to tell whether full-on “no-deal” preparation was necessary or not.But now No  is indicating that it wants to hold off until after the meaningful vote in Parliament on December .This is deeply irresponsible.Those inside the machine estimate that it would take four months of intense preparations to get this country into a place where it could make no deal manageable.So, by waiting until after the meaningful vote, the Government is denying itself valuable time.I am told that new Brexit Secretary Steve Barclay, who will update Cabinet on no-deal preparedness on Tuesday, is frustrated at the foot- dragging by No . A growing number of other ministers share this concern.Theresa May, of course doesn’t want no deal. She wants Parliament to approve the deal she has negotiated.But, right now, it is hard to see how it passes.The DUP have said they won’t vote for it, denying the Government its majority, and  Tory MPs have declared they will vote against it — ­suggesting the Government is on course for a heavy defeat.“It is increasingly dficult to see what rescues this,” said one of those charged with getting it through.Given thatthe withdrawal agreement is defeated and nothing is put in its place then this country leaves the EU without a deal, it is foolish not to massively intensy planning for that outcome.At every point since the ­referendum, the Government has put off crucial decisions on no-deal planning.This has weakened the UK’s negotiating position and means the UK is now ill-prepared for what Mrs May admits is one of the three most likely outcomes.The situation is so serious that one member of the Privy Council told me this week that the military should be drafted in to help.This former Cabinet minister’s argument was that only the military had the logistical know-how to ensure that ­critical supplies make it all around the country in time.May still hasn’t given up on getting the withdrawal agreement through Parliament.But there is little sign of a decisive sht in her favour.Cabinet ministers are still talking in terms of the scale of defeat, rather than of victory.The expectation among ­ministers is thatMay loses the vote by  or less, she will seek clarication on the ­backstop and then try and bring it back to the Commons.But, as one leading member of the Cabinet warns, May will have to move fast.If she loses the meaningful vote she “could face the  letters and a vote of no confidence in short order”.THE Housing Secretary, James Brokenshire, has scored a ­signicant victory over the Chancellor.Brokenshire wanted to reduce the maximum deposit that renters would have to pay from six weeks’ rent to five.The idea was that this would be fairer on tenants who must find the money for the deposit up front. But Philip Hammond objected.The Chancellor wrote to Cabinet colleagues that “I cannot agree to the proposed concession to lower the deposit cap from six weeks’ rent to five weeks’ rent.“Six weeks’ rent was already placing landlords at risk of uncovered loss for damage to property, as well as risk of loss of rent.“This bill was always a high- risk measure. A cap of six weeks’ rent was already a major concession and I believe we have to hold the line at this level.”However, Hammond’s objections have not carried the day. The Government will now back reducing the deposit cap to five weeks for all but the most expensive properties.One of the Tories’ biggest problems is being seen as the landlords’ party. Hammond himself declares rental income of more than £,.In , the Tories were more popular than Labour among those who rented in the private sector.But at the last election, ­Labour had a -point lead over the Tories among private renters.The Tories won’t win these voters back by dragging their feet on measures that make le easier for tenants.SENIOR Labour figures are plotting a route to an early General Election that doesn’t involve having to get two thirds of the Commons to vote for it.One close ally of Jeremy Corbyn in the Shadow Cabinet tells me that the plan would be to defeat the Government in a confidence motionthe ­Government loses the meaningful vote.The idea would be to persuade the DUP to join with Labour and the other opposition parties in voting against the Government. This would result in a narrow defeat for Theresa May.At that point, the Fixed Term Parliament Act allows  days for the Commons to approve an alternative government.In these circumstances, no government could be approved – the DUP wouldn’t actively put ­Corbyn into No  while no Tory leader could be elected in that time who would meet the DUP’s requirements on the backstop.The result of all this would be that with ­Parliament deadlocked, there would have to be another General Election.How realistic the Labour front bench consider this scenario is crucial. For there is mounting tension in the Shadow Cabinet about whether or not Labour should formally back a second referendum.At the moment, Labour’s policy is to push for a General Election above all .But this week, John McDonnell – the Shadow Chancellor – admitted that securing a General Election was “very dficult” so the party may well back a second referendum instead.TORY party donors have received a letter from party HQ defending the deal that Theresa May has ­negotiated.Attached to the letter is a rather revealing document setting out why “the backstop is needed in all scenarios”.It lists four future scenarios for UK EU relations – a Canada-style trade deal, EEA membership, a UK EU customs union and the UK being in both the customs union and the single market.Three of these four options would be deemed unacceptable by most Brexiteer MPs.WHEN the then Culture Secretary Matt Hancock scrapped Leveson , the next stage of the inquiry into the Press, critics claimed that either Parliament or the courts would force him into a U-turn.But the key votes in the Commons were won, and this week the courts rejected the appeal for a judicial review of the decision.With Labour having gone cold on Section , which would have forced newspapers to sign up to a state regulator or pay both sides’ costs in disputes, the freedom of the Press remains.The challenge now is never to allow it to be threatened in this way again.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The plain looking copper-alloy ring bears the inscription of Pilatus which experts believe refers to the infamous Pontius Pilate.The Bible tells how Pilate was a prefect of Rome and governor of Judea who bowed to pressure from chief priests to kill Jesus.The stamping ring  -used to sign documents - was found in  by Prof Gideon Forster from the Hebrew University of Jerusalem.It was discovered on the site of a fortress built by King Herod - known as the King of the Jews - between  and BC.Thousands of artefacts were discovered at the site and the ring was one of many found in Herods actual burial tomb.The engraving was only revealed recently, when the ring was cleaned and examined, showing the words surrounded by a wine vessel.A stamping ring represents status in the Roman cavalry, to which Pilate is recorded to have belonged.Prof Danny Schwartz told Haaretz: I dont know of any other Pilatus from the period and the ring shows he was a person of stature and wealth.You can see he had a natural link to the Herodion. Even for Herod it was more than just a tomb site with a palace.It was also a signicant site of government. title: french parents smacking ban children law
story: The French Parliament today voted to outlaw corporal punishment or humiliation after  per cent of parents admitted hitting their child.The new law means parental authority is exercised without violence of any sort - including physical, verbal or psychological violence.MPs voted - following a debate last night and the bill will now be passed to the Senate.Previous attempts to outlaw smacking in French homes have been quashed by the government.Schools have not been allowed to physically punish children for many years but parents have not been barred under the current laws.MP Maud Petit, who sponsored the measure, said the bills main goal was educational - to encourage society to change its views on the issue.The country was singled out in  by human rights organisation the Council of Europe for failing to ban smacking despite its European neighbours already making it illegal.The UN Committee on the Rights of the Child took up the issue a year later - calling on France to explicitly prohibit all forms of corporal punishment of youngsters.They pointed to evidence showing children suffer both mentally and physically when smacked.If the bill is adopted, France will become the th state to ban corporal punishment of children.In the UK, it is illegal for a parent or carer to smack their own child, except where it amounts to reasonable punishment, according to section  of the Children Act .Hitting a child in a way which causes wounding, actual bodily harm, grievous bodily harm or child cruelty are all illegal.And the smacking of kids by teachers, nursery workers and child care workers - which was once allowed - is now banned.This defence is laid down in section  of the Children Act , but it is not defined in this legislation.Whether a ‘smack’ amounts to reasonable punishment will depend on the circumstances of each case, taking into consideration factors like the age of the child and the nature of the smack.There are strict guidelines covering the use of reasonable punishment and it will not be possible to rely on the defenceyou use severe physical punishment on your child which amounts to wounding, actual bodily harm, grievous bodily harm or child cruelty.Because of the confusion surrounding what is or isnt an offence, the Director of Public Prosecutions for England and Wales has produced a charging standard.For even more serious injuries - resulting in cuts, multiple bruising, fractures, broken bones, broken teeth or loss of conscious - a parent could be charged under Actual Bodily Harm.However, the law in Scotland is changing now - meaning the reasonable punishment defence will no longer apply north of the border.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: The shocking symbol used by Adolf Hitlers Nazi Party has also reportedly turned up on points of interest in Edinburgh, Dublin and Las Vegas.Appalled social media users have shared screenshots of the disturbing digital blunder in bizarre posts online.Andy Ingram wrote: Excuse me Google but why are your maps showing London hotels with swastikas on the pins He included pictures of the disturbing symbol appearing on pins for several hotels in the English capital.And another mfed Maps user from Dublin tweeted: Google Maps, can you tell me why the hotels in Dublin have swastika signs on them The swastika is based on an ancient symbol of good luck and spirituality used for thousands of years in Indian religions and East Asian cultures.But it became affiliated with fascism, antisemitism and racism when Hitler appropriated the symbol to associate it with the Aryan race.Google says that the reason the symbol is on its Maps service is that the image is not a swastika, but rather a Buddhist symbol of worship.They said: Were aware that these religious symbols are incorrectly displaying for certain hotels, and are working on a fix to restore the correct hotel icon to these places.

title: theresa may g20 summit falklands argentina trade talks
story: May held a private meeting with the Argentine President Mauricio Macri as she is in the South American country for the G summit.Diplomatic relations between the two countries have been tense since the conflict as Argentina also lays claim to the islands in the South Atlantic.The Prime Minister though has emphasised the Falklands will remain British despite the talks earlier this evening focusing on trade.May said: “I am talking to president Macri about opportunities for trade, but our position on the sovereignty of the Falklands hasnt changed – and will not change.”The meeting comes after the two countries agreed a new air link between South America and the Falklands, going via Argentina.The British government said in a statement that it was part of “building closer links” which were a shared goal between the two countries.The Argentine Foreign Minister Jorge Faurie said the new link was a positive development and added “dialogue must be maintained.”May also used the summit to also hold face-to-face talks with other leaders around the world – most notably Australia, Canada, Japan, Chile and Turkey.During her talks with Japan she was urged to avoid a No Deal Brexit.Japan’s Prime Minister Shinzo Abe paid tribute to Mrs May’s “leadership” in managing to get an agreement with the EU.But piling pressure on the PM, he implored: “I would like to once again ask for your support to avoid No Deal as well as to ensure transparency, predictability as well as legal stability in the Brexit process.”The blast comes just weeks after Japanese investors warned Britain would lose its standing as the ‘gateway to Europe’ in a No Deal. Panasonic has already moved its European HQ to Amsterdam.In February the Tokyo’s ambassador warned any “private company” would be unable to continue operations in the UKit became unprofitable.Trade has topped Mrs Mays agenda for the two-day gathering, as she sought to push her global Britain message of new opportunities, which she believes will be opened by the UKs withdrawal from the EU.The exception has been a bilateral meeting with Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, where the PM delivered a robust message over the death of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the need for Riyadh to engage in talks in Stockholm next week on ending the war in Yemen.Following the meeting, a Downing Street spokesman said: The Prime Minister stressed the importance of ensuring that those responsible for the appalling murder of Jamal Khashoggi are held to account, and that Saudi Arabia takes action to build confidence that such a deplorable incident could not happen again.Noting the steps taken by the Saudi investigation since the Foreign Secretary had met with the crown prince and King Salman on November , she encouraged the crown prince to ensure that Saudi Arabia co-operated fully with the Turkish authorities and worked to bring both investigations to an acceptable close.To ensure full accountability, there needed to be full transparency about exactly what had happened and who was responsible, in line with the commitments made by King Salman when she spoke to him on October .

title: theresa may g20 speech brexit prime minister eu
story: Just  hours after another Ministerial resignation the defiant PM said she would be talking to inidual MPs all week to try and win them round.And challenged by The Sun that she could soon be out of a job, she declared she was going nowhere.She declared: “There’s a lot more for me still to do.“Not least delivering on Brexit and being the Prime Minister who does take the UK out off the European Union.”Mrs May said the country faced a “really important” week as the Commons begins a mammoth debate on her Brexit deal with the EU.Sources claim the PM could lose by a humiliating  votes on December - throwing the country into chaos and leaving her clinging onto No by her fingertips.And she added: “The next nine days are a really important time for the country leading up to the vote on the deal. I will be talking to MPs, explaining to them why this is a good deal for the United Kingdom.“It is a deal that delivers on Brexit and also a deal that protects jobs and the economy.”She added: “I think allowing this deal to go through, passing this deal in the vote that will take place House of Commons, will take us to certainty for the future.”She confirmed she would be spending much of the week on a blitz of rebel Tories attempting to talk them round.May also said the UK will be able to strike independent free trade deals with countries around the world, should her Brexit proposal get accepted.But in a fresh blow today Sky News revealed at least a third of her own trade envoys plan to vote down the agreement.The MPs - charged with fostering links with nations around the world - claim her soft Brexit deal means its impossible for them to strike trade agreements.The PM insisted the EU agreement would allow the UK to have its own independent trade policy for over  years.The Prime Minister, speaking in Buenos Aires in Argentina, said she had checked with the European Union that Britain would be able to strike deals with countries around the world, under the terms of her agreement.May added that during the summit other leaders had made it clear they were keen to sign a trade deal as soon as possible.Earlier in the day the Prime Minister held bilateral talks with a number of world leaders, including a private meeting with the Argentine President Mauricio Macri – the first time a Conservative PM had held talks with the country’s leader since the Falklands War in .Diplomatic relations between the two countries have been tense since the conflict as Argentina also lays claim to the islands in the South Atlantic.May also used the summit to also hold face-to-face talks with other leaders around the world – most notably Australia, Canada, Japan, Chile and Turkey.

title: mohammed bin salman tells macron
story: NewsMohammed bin Salman tells Macron dont worry in tense talk about Khashoggi murderEmmanuel Macron confronted Saudi Arabia Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman regarding the murder of Saudi dissident journalist Jamal KhashoggiShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  NOV Updated:,  DEC Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news politics video mbs-tells-macron-dont-worry-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailEmmanuel Macron confronted Saudi Arabian Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman over the murder of Jamal Khashoggi at the G summit. The French President told the de-facto Saudi ruler that international experts need to be involved in the investigation into his death. Mr Macrons demand came shortly before Theresa May held face-to-face talks with the crown prince in which she promised to send a robust message about the murder, as well as the war in Yemen. Bin Salman has appeared isolated among fellow world leaders at the G summit in Argentina, with the exception of a vigorous public handshake from Russias Vladimir Putin - himself treated as a pariah by some of those present. The crown prince was filmed in an apparently tense conversation with Mr Macron, telling the French president not to worry. Mr Macron responded: I am worried...You never listen to me.   The widely-shared video showed bin Salman replying: I will listen, of course. It concluded with Mr Macron saying: I am a man of my word. Later, an Elysee Palace official said the president had conveyed a very firm message on the need for international involvement in the Khashoggi investigation, currently the subject of two separate probes by Saudi Arabia and Turkey. Mrs May said she would use her meeting to press Britains call for a credible and transparent investigation into Mr Khashoggis death in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul in October and urge Mohammed to ensure his country offers full co-operation to the Turkish investigation.   Mrs May was also pressing the Crown Prince to ensure his countrys engagement in talks in Stockholm next week to find a political solution to the bloodshed in Yemen, where a Saudi-led coalition is fighting Houthi rebels. Amnesty International UKs director Kate Allen said Mrs May should politely but firmly insist that only a UN investigation into the grisly murder of Jamal Khashoggi is going to be sufficient. Speaking to Sky News ahead of the meeting, Mrs May said: It is the relationship we have with Saudi Arabia that enables me to sit down with him and be robust on our views on two issues. On the Khashoggi case, she said Riyadh must ensure that their investigation is a full investigation, that it is credible, that it is transparent and that people can have confidence in the outcome of it and that those responsible are held to account.   And she said she was very concerned about the humanitarian situation in Yemen resulting from the long-running conflict. Now is the time, there is an opportunity to find a solution, said the PM. I will be encouraging all parties, including the Saudi Arabians, to ensure that they sit down at the upcoming UN-led talks in Stockholm in the coming days and weeks and find a way through this, find a political solution for a stable future for Yemen. Mrs May also held talks with the summits host, President Mauricio Macri, at which the long-standing dispute over the sovereignty of the Falklands took a back seat as discussions focused on trade.   Mrs May presented keen Queen fan Macri with a book about the rock band, while the Argentine president gave her a special cup for drinking national beverage Yerba Mate herbal tea. Mrs May is the first Conservative Prime Minister to visit Argentina since the  war, and only the second serving PM to do so, after Tony Blair briefly crossed the border from Brazil in . Mr Macri has toned down official rhetoric over the islands Argentina knows as Las Malvinas since taking over from Cristina Kirchner in . This weeks announcement of a new air link between the Falklands and the South American mainland via Argentina has been greeted in London as an indication that relations are headed in a positive direction. Speaking during her flight to Buenos Aires, Mrs May said the establishment of the flight showed a dferent relationship developing. I am talking to President Macri about issues about trade and opportunities for trade, but our position on the sovereignty of the Falklands hasnt changed and will not change, she added.

title: strictly brexit tv debates need
story: NewsopinionThe Strictly Brexit TV debates need to be done properly - with Theresa, Jeremy, and Craig Revel HorwoodAny chance of a phone vote, too ShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get Im a Celebrity updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe idea of a second season of Brexit debates may well be the least welcome franchise reboot in television history.But hang on - theyre going to be linked to Im A Celebrity and Strictly Come Dancing, you say  Book Craig Revel Horwood and buy some fresh kangaroo balls! LETS DO THIS.In the opening credits, a glitterball with the word SOVEREIGNTY flies in across the Australian rainforest. The camera pans to a grim-faced Tess Daly, stood in Elstree Studios in army fatigues and camouflage paint. Good evening and welcome to Strictly Brexit... Get Me Out Of Here! Next to her, Declan Donnelly - in a gorgeous pink floaty ballgown perfect for the Viennese waltz - shouts: Its politics week, and our final contestants are going head-to-head in the shout-off. Please welcome, Theresa May and Jeremy Corbyn!The studio audience clap despondently in the trees as Theresa abseils to the ground dressed as a giant sequinned eagle . Jeremy joins her in a small wheeled kayak filled with cockroaches all muttering about Palestine.The two take up position at podiums in the centre of the dancefloor, as forest rangers screw large, transparent plastic boxes to their heads.  Dec adopts his concerned voice as he says: Theresa and Jeremy, you have  minutes to convince the public your version of Brexit will work. But you will not be alone out there.Tess continues: Theresa, you will have , miniature backbenchers added to your box. For legal reasons, I must warn you they can bite, but will probably not manage a decent coup detat.Dec turns to her opponent. Jeremy, your box contains enough oxygen for you to survive. But every time you do that shouty geography teacher thing, ask Diane Abbott for help or fail to pick a side, some of your oxygen will be removed. He continues: Keir Starmer will also stand behind you, whispering things you dont understand. Tess then indicates a camp fire around which are gathered Bruno Tonioli, Shirley Ballas, Darcey Bussell and Craig Revel Horwood. Please welcome our judges, who will deliver their verdict on your technical performance. You will be subject to a phone vote and at the end of the show one of you WILL be leaving the contest. Spotlights fall upon the pair, and Theresa speaks first. Im standing up for Britain, she begins, then squeaks as a Jacob bites her on the nose and tells her shes hysterical. This is a deal that will give us control of our borders, she continues, while an Arlene crawls into her ear demanding Northern Ireland has special treatment but is also treated just the same. This is the best we could hope for, she adds as a Boris slithers down her blouse looking for his point.Jeremy then takes his turn. We respect the referendum, but were going to stop the government acting on it, he says, with a cough. Theresa has botched the deal, and we could do a better onewe just go back to the start again, he gasps. A second referendum is an option but we prefer a... general election... we had a peoples vote already...he continues breathlessly, going blue in the face.Nobody is ruling out remain, Keir whispers. Jeremys eyes bulge. Keir goes on: We need single market access or the economy will collapse. Jeremy begins clawing at his box. John McDonnell isnt your friend any more, hisses Keir, as Jeremy tries to smash the box against the podium.Tess and Dec practice their sad faces. And now, lets ask our judges for advice, says Tess. Darcey  Are you an enemy of the people   The former ballerina lts her head from her hands. Theresa, your framing was excellent but the footwork makes no sense. You need to really point those toes, yes, arch your nose a little more, yes She collapses back into ennui as Bruno leaps to his feet, grinds his pelvis and shouts: THERESA THE PLEASER! My God, woman, the way you travelled the floor with those backbenchers trying to destroy you reminded me of Anton du Beke and Ann Widdecombe. You are the one to beat, but I must admit my darling the footwork was a little illogical, you havent really sold it to me. The camera pans to Craig, whose face resembles the morning after a whisky bottle and a bad break-up. The whole thing has been a dis-AAAAAAAA-ster, darlings. Neither of you made me happy, you both fudged your fleckles, and Im afraid the only paddle youll see is when the nation tells you both to get in the sea, darling.Dec turns to Shirley. Youre head judge and have the casting vote. What do you think  Shirley titters: Oh I agree with all my fellow judges! Arent they great! Were best friends!  Tess turns to Theresa, by this point writhing on the floor as a tiny Andrew Bridgen kicks her in the teeth, and Jeremy, who has gone purple while being throttled by Keir Starmers Blairite tie.We go now to the results of the phone vote. Jeremy, you got... NO votes of approval. Theresa, you got... NO votes of approval. So we go to the votes of disapproval, she says.She takes a deep breath. Jeremy, you got disapproval votes from the majority of your shadow cabinet, your parliamentary party, and your party membership as a whole. Theresa, you got parliamentary disapproval votes only from Boris, Jacob and their friends, but also Im afraid the vast majority of your party members, Brexiters, Remainers, and readers of the .Overall, neither of you has won. So we go to sudden death.A crash of drums, and a spotlight falls upon stage left. Dec says: You will now present your business plans to Claude Littner. Claude enters, flanked by feather-covered dancers. This is a bloody disgrace!, he barks. Theresa, none of your figures add up. Ive read through your deal and its exceptional. Exceptionally BAD, that is. If this had been suggested on day  it would have been laughed out. And Jeremy. Youre talking nonsense, arent you  Quite clearly the statements youre making are ludicrous. Youre not a big fish. Youre not even a fish! Frankly, youre both parasites. This contest is terminated.Claude exits. Tess and Dec look at each other and the cameras, uncertain of what to do. In their earpieces, a producer wonders about the wisdom of getting Mr Blobby on with a bucket of crocodile eyes. Bollocks to this, says a member of the audience, standing up. Youre all hopeless. No-one voted for the Tories to disentegrate, no-ones pointed out this is a transition agreement, not the actual deal. If youre all this hopeless just limbering up, what hope do we have of winning the thing  Ive heard enough. Youre all bloody fired.  We wont get any that, of course. Those who organise political debates rarely include a gunge machine, and politicians who behave like infants whove lost a rattle ironically think such stunts would be childish.Instead, the broadcasters will put the debate on just before the Im A Celeb final or after the Strictly semi-final. The question is not who gets voted out, but whether its a BBC audience, a more-plebby ITV one, and whether anyone will watch for more than  minutes.Which is a shame, because as a country we have more faith in X Factor phone votes than we do the ones cast in the ballot box.

title: autistic woman tears debenhams staff
story: NewsAutistic woman in tears as Debenhams staff march her out of shop for no reasonKatie Cornwall, , of Hull claims she was followed out of Boots by security, who she believes called ahead to Debenhams to warn them that she may be heading thereShareCommentsByDan Kemp:,  DEC NewsKatie Cornwall, , on the right, and her mum Catherine "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA vulnerable woman was reduced to tears when she was marched out of Debenhams - even though she had done nothing wrong. Katie Cornwall, , suffers from Asperger’s syndrome, so at times she does not understand her surroundings in the same way others would. Miss Cornwall regularly shops in Hull and often wears bed socks and UGG boots, even at the height of summer, because it makes her feel comfortable. However following a shopping trip to Boots and Debenhams on Thursday, she was left in floods of tears. Hull Live reports that her mum, Catherine Cornwall, claims her daughter was followed out of Boots by security staff. She believes staff then called ahead to Debenhams to warn them that she may be heading there, which led to her being evicted from the store. She says she is dismayed at how her daughter’s condition was treated by staff. Boots has already issued an apology for an “honest misunderstanding” while Debenhams has encouraged them to contact the store manager. Catherine says that while the biggest impact has been felt by her daughter, she has also been left distraught by what happened. “I’ve been in bits this morning thinking she was just getting somewhere but it’s set her back,” she said.  “In Katie’s mind, they were keeping a close eye on her. She felt that they were on her. Katie began by shopping in Boots, where she was buying Christmas gts for her boyfriend, before moving on to the Prospect Street department store, where she claims she was “marched out” by security. Katie’s mum believes it is more likely that she felt hassled to leave after picking up on security guards paying extra attention to her in both shops, and would have felt more pressured than usual given her autistic Asberger’s syndrome. Explaining what she claims happened to her daughter during her trip, Catherine said: “She has autistic Asperger’s. She dresses dferently but that’s her only crime. “She ended up in tears. She said the security had been watching her in Boots and she said she went across to Debenhams and they marched her out the shop. “She’d been looking at some children’s clothing which fit her because she’s really tiny. She’d done nothing wrong.” Katie only looks like a teenager according to her mum, which could have raised suspicions. She often takes the bus into Hull from her home in Patrington to look around the shops and to treat herself as well as her partner, but her mum now says the experience might have put her off venturing into town on her own again. “She goes around and looks around by herself looking at things,” Catherine said.  “I don’t knowshe wants to go in those places ever again. She went back to my mum’s saying she daren’t go into town again. “She’s a vulnerable adult. If you’re a vulnerable adult, you shouldn’t be picked out.” Catherine is now calling for more understanding from staff in shops to make sure others aren’t left feeling as uncomfortable as her daughter did. “I can’t believe thatsomeone looks dferent they would call around all the shops saying to watch out for her. “Not everyone is perfect and I want people to be aware of people’s dferences.” In a statement, a spokeswoman for Boots UK apologised for the misunderstanding. They have also offered to meet with the family so they can once again feel comfortable while shopping at the store. The statement reads: “We would like to take this opportunity to reiterate our sincere apologies for this honest misunderstanding and for any inconvenience or distress caused. In a statement, a spokeswoman for Boots UK apologised for the misunderstanding. They have also offered to meet with the family so they can once again feel comfortable while shopping at the store. The statement reads: “We would like to take this opportunity to reiterate our sincere apologies for this honest misunderstanding and for any inconvenience or distress caused. “At Boots UK, we take the safety of our customers and stores very seriously and we work closely with an independent security specialist to make sure that effective security measures and procedures are in place across all UK stores.” Meanwhile, a spokesman for Debenhams said: “Debenhams provides an inclusive shopping environment to all customers and is dismayed to hear this complaint. “We encourage the customer to contact the store manager directly to discuss the details of the incident further.”

title: baby born size chocolate bar
story: NewsBaby born the size of a CHOCOLATE BAR makes it home for ChristmasTiny Sussie Bea Patrick weighed just one pound and one ounce when she was born four months early,  weeks into mum Jodie Marrins pregnancyShareCommentsByEmilia Bona:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsSussie was so small, she was the size of a chocolate bar when she was born "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA tiny baby born four months early has made it home with her proud parents in time for Christmas.Sussie Bea Patrick defied all the odds when she was born  weeks and four days into mum Jodie Marrins pregnancy, at the size of a chocolate bar.Doctors told the -year-old mum and her partner Lee Patrick, , to expect the worst, the Liverpool ECHO reports.Their darling girl would have no quality of le should she survive, medics said. But Jodie and Lee refused to give up on her and now will spend their first Christmas with little Sussie.Born weighing just one pound and one ounce, Lee believes his daughter may be the smallest baby ever cared for at Arrowe Park Hospital, Wirral.  Now, five months after she came into the world, Sussie made it home from the neonatal unit to be with her family in time for Christmas. Lee Patrick, who lives in Birkenhead, said that his partners pregnancy was perfectly normal and healthy - with no indication Sussie would be born so prematurely. Everything was fine with mum all the way through, he said.It was sepsis - mum contracted it or baby contracted a bug and passed it on to Jodie. She was feeling unwell for about  hours. When it got to .pm on June  I said were going to the hospital, this isnt right.  She was throwing up. Within  minutes she was giving birth in the back of the taxi to hospital.Within about  minutes Sussie literally slid out. I grabbed her and said help! This was in Arrowe Park in one of the triage wards.About  minutes after we got to the hospital she gave birth. With Sussie being born so early, her mum and dad were warned their daughters chances of survival were virtually non-existant.  Just as they were welcoming their baby girl into the world, Lee and Jodie were told they would need to say their goodbyes. Lee said: We were told that when she came out we would have to say our goodbyes. They said she wouldnt be breathing for long and might not look like we expected.They said they would let us be together as a family. She came out and gave a little whimper so they started working on her. We were told it wasnt worth [treating her].They said she wouldnt have a quality of le but we said look thats something that we will have to deal with butshes fighting we have to fight. And shes here now.  Back home with her mum and dad in Birkenhead, Sussie is still on oxygen but Lee says his daughter is perfect and called her his little miracle. The family lived in Ronald McDonald House at Arrowe Park for three and a half months after Sussie was born - and Lee said shes become something of a celebrity at the hospital. Lee said lots of the neonatal staff and nurses at the hospital recognise Sussie, and that the family became incredibly close with the staff while she was receiving treatment. Having been through the wars and back Lee and Jodie are over the moon their little fighter is home in time for Christmas with the family that never gave up on her. Lee will be taking part in this years Santa Dash along with another dad to a premature baby girl in aid of Ronald McDonald House at Arrowe Park.
