title: brave-abseilers-line-up-to-remember-north-berwicks-dennis-baron
story: Fteen of Dennis Baronrsquos closest friends and family abseiled down Barns Ness Lighthouse for charity.Now they could do something each year to raise further funds for a good cause.Among those making their way down one of East Lothianrsquos tallest buildings was his daughter, Kirsty.She said: ldquoIt went absolutely phenomenally.ldquoWe raised over pound,, which is just beyond our wildest dreams.ldquoWe thought half of that, at a push, but pound, is amazing, absolutely amazing.ldquoI was terried for three days beforehand ndash I was living on adrenaline.Dennis had lived in North Berwick for more than  years and previously worked at the Ben Sayers Factory and the townrsquos Co-op store.Thirty years ago, he was diagnosed with Hodgkinrsquos lymphoma before being diagnosed a second time just two years later.Kirsty said: ldquoOn his th birthday he was diagnosed with Hodgkinrsquos lymphoma again and went through gruelling treatment ndash radiotherapy and chemotherapy.ldquoThen, five years ago, on his th birthday, he was diagnosed with bowel cancer and had a serious operation when he lost an amount of his bowel.Dennis, who passed away on Easter Sunday, later signed a consent form for Professor Malcolm Dunlop, professor of coloproctology and consultant colorectal surgeon at Edinburghrsquos Western General Hospital, to do research.Kirsty, along with her brother Steven and sister-in-law Lorna Baron, son Kieran and daughter Gemma, were among those heading to the lighthouse, near Dunbar.She said: ldquoThe adrenaline was pumping and me and my son went up first.ldquoThere are  steps and I ploughed up there ndash I have never taken steps so quickly.ldquoI had a bit of a wait at the top and then trying to get my balance.However, the -year-old would soon be back on solid ground and with a renewed enthusiasm to do another fundraiser next September.Kirsty, of Gilbert Avenue, said: ldquoMy mum said to me lsquoyour dad would be super proud but would never tell you that!rsquoldquoHe did not want a fuss.ldquoWe have got to try to get a cure for this awful disease and try to help somebody  so they do not go through what we have been through.ldquoI keep going back and looking at the video of the abseil on my phone and I feel sick!ldquoWe have discussed doing something  and we will be back next year in September.ldquoI have suggested a tandem skye but the response was just grunts.ldquoMaybe we will do a big charity cycle, from Inverness to Fort William, something to raise awareness of cancer.To make a donation, go to justgiving fundraising dennisbaron or text DWBA to .

title: mcdonalds-flasher-made-helicopter-like-moves-with-his-genitals
story: Musselburgh man Ryan Dolan dropped his trousers and pants while at the takeaway outlet at South St Andrews Street in Edinburgh earlier this year.The -year-old jumped onto the counter and pretended to serve customers before performing a bizarre dance which saw him use ldquohelicopter-like moves with his genitals.Edinburgh Sherf Court was told that police attended following the incident on July  and identied Dolan from CCTV footage.Dolan, of Millhill Wynd, was subsequently arrested and charged the next day.Dolan appeared at the city court last Wednesday, where he pleaded guilty to committing an act of public indecency at the McDonaldrsquos by dancing naked and exposing his genitals.Fiscal depute Nicole Lavelle told the court that Dolan arrived at the outlet at about am and soon began his naked antics as staff served customers.Ms Lavelle said: ldquoOut of the blue he took off his trousers and pants, showing off his penis and testicles, and was dancing with his trousers down.ldquoHe grabbed his penis and started to play with it pretending to serve customers and started dancing again, carrying out helicopter-like moves with his penis.The court was told that Dolan had two previous convictions for similar offences and was fined pound.Dolan admitted to committing an act of indecency by repeatedly removing his trousers and pants, making gestures with his penis, and dancing naked in front of staff and members of the public at McDonaldrsquos, Edinburgh, on July .

title: man-walked-into-exs-home-uninvited-and-refused-to-leave
story: Scott Hardie, of Winton Park, also acted aggressively towards two men during the incident at an address at Rig Place, Aberlady, in October.Hardie, , arrived at the home of the woman and let himself through an unlocked door before telling her he was not leaving.The woman called a friend, Sunny Ahmed, and he called the police before heading towards the home.Once the police had arrived, Hardie began threatening two men with violence and he was arrested.Fiscal depute Mark Keane told Edinburgh Sherf Court: ldquoOn October  at around .am the woman was within her home and the accused walked through an open door into the living room. She asked him to leave and then she called the police.ldquoThe police spoke to the accused in the front room and the woman was said to have looked fearful. She didnrsquot want to make a complaint but wanted him removed from the house.ldquoOn leaving the property, the accused saw Mr Ahmed and Richard Gordon and began shouting abuse and threats towards them.The Crown also moved for a non-harassment order to be granted against Hardie.Defending solicitor Rebecca Weissgerber said her client now acknowledged the relationship he had with the woman was over and told the court that Hardie had analogous convictions. She said the five-year relationship was at an end and that he had turned up that day ldquohoping for them to get back together.Sherf John Cook deferred sentence for the preparation of social work reports.Hardie admitted behaving in a threatening or abusive manner by entering a home uninvited, refusing to leave, acting aggressively towards Sunny Ahmed and Richard Gordon, and uttering threats of violence at Rig Street, Aberlady, on October .

title: tranents-radio-saltire-to-launch-on-fm-this-weekend
story: Radio Saltire will raise the FM flag from its studios on Civic Square when it takes to the airwaves at am on Sunday.Trustees at the community radio station, which already attracts about , listeners a day as an online station, are confident the FM station will attract about five times that amount.Iain Swanston, programme controller, said: ldquoAt Radio Saltire, we aim to raise standards to a new level. Interest in the stationrsquos move to FM has been tremendous and the support from MSPs, the local councillors, businesses and the community has been amazing.The station has been broadcasting   since . Earlier this year it was granted a licence to broadcast on FM, which it is hoped will help it attract more than , listeners on . and .FM.Mr Swanston added: ldquoThe new FM station will offer a wide range of programmes.ldquoWe aim to be the lsquoVoice of East Lothianrsquo.ldquoShows will cover a host of popular music genres with local news, information and features.ldquoWe will have a wide iety of special interest programmes and encourage the local people and community groups to get involved as well as being a  for unsigned local bands, singers and artists.The station will play host to more than  volunteer presenters throughout the week and will continue to broadcast  hours a day.Mr Swanston thanked everyone for their support.He added: ldquoThe support for Radio Saltire from the people of East Lothian has been absolutely tremendous and we are confident that we will provide a community radio station that will be at the heart of the community.East Lothian will now have two locally based stations on FM as Haddington-based East Coast FM broadcasts on ..

title: prestonpans-girl-lights-up-jenners-christmas-tree
story: Bella Rennie lit up Jennersrsquo ft-tall tree at pm on Sunday, November , in front of crowds of shoppers, who gathered on each floor of the famous Princes Street department store.Joined by her proud mum Jane and little sister Poppy, Bella had the task of bringing a little bit of early festive cheer and switching on , lights all at once.Her mum said: ldquoIt was a lovely surprise and completely not the sort of thing you can expect to be asked. The girls were really excited.ldquoWe went with the people from Jenners and had a walk through the forest at Kelty looking at trees. Some were too big, some were not right and the girls got to pick one.ldquoIt was lovely to see it sitting in the store. It was a bit of an unusual experience but quite exciting and Bella felt like a bit of a celebrity.The youngster, from Prestonpans, has visited and stayed in Edinburghrsquos Royal Hospital for Sick Children regularly since she was diagnosed with brain and spinal tumours aged just two.During her time there, Edinburgh Childrenrsquos Hospital Charityhas supported and cared for her.Jane added: ldquoECHC have done wonders to make sure that Bella doesnrsquot miss out on her childhood when shersquos in hospital ndash from art and crafts to storytelling, the charity makes sure that Bella has a familiar face and a fun activity to keep her busy.The opportunity to switch on the tree lights at Jenners was donated to an ECHC auction by the department store.The prize was won by two women who donated it back to the charity for a child.Jane said: ldquoEven though we are back and forth, the hospital staff always recognise Bella and they know us.ldquoIt is really nice to be asked to do something like this.Amy Ford, corporate fundraiser at ECHC, said: ldquoThanks to our donors, children like Bella can still have fun, activities and surprises while at hospital.ldquoChristmas is such a magical time of year for us all, and wersquore doing all we can to make sure that children and young people who will be spending theirs in hospital this year donrsquot miss out.ldquoSo, this December, wersquore asking the public to get involved in any way they can and help us make Christmas at the RHSC a warm and memorable experience.The public can help bring the magic to the hospital this Christmas by texting DOOR to  to donate pound, or by donating online at ech charity.org

title: former-home-of-legendary-east-lothian-golfer-up-for-sale
story: Just a pitch from the townrsquos West Links, St Helens at  West End Place, North Berwick, was the first home of local golfing legend Jean Donald, a star golfer in the s and s.It is now on the market with Gilson Gray for offers over pound,.The detached, seven-bedroom property is set over three floors and offers views out to the sea, the harbour and Craigleith and the Bass Rock.Gail Walshe, property manager at Gilson Gray, said: ldquoIt is rare for a property like St Helens to come onto the market.ldquoThere is a iety of living spaces in the house and plenty of potential for the buyer to put their own stamp on the property. However, the real draw ndash besides the housersquos prime location ndash is its heritage.ldquoJean Donald is a golfing legend in this part of the country, so by purchasing St Helens you would be buying a slice of local history.Born in  at the Victorian property, Jean was selected several times to play in the Curtis Cup for the British and Northern Ireland team.During her le, Jean won a string of accolades including the Ladies French Open Championship in  and the Sunningdale Open Foursomes four times, twice with partner Peter Alliss. She also won the Scottish Ladies Championship in ,  and .She even caused controversy by daring to wear trousers in the  Scottish Amateur Championship.Jean died in , at the age of .

title: teacher-tells-class-to-donate-to-foodbank-instead-of-buying-her-gifts
story: Kate McLaughlan, from Newark Primary School in Port Glasgow, Scotland, explained in a letter to parents and carers that the donations to Inverclyde Foodbank will teach the children ldquothe spirit of giving and kindness.She will send blank envelopes home with the pupils into which donations can be placed, before the students will gather together on December  to count the money and write a shopping list for the foodbank.What a lovely and kind thing to dohellip.well done Mrs McLaughlan! Not only is it a very thoughtful thing to do but a great example to our kids as well ##Share away people ##Posted by Linsey Milloy onThursday, November , ldquoPlease do not feel you have to donate andyou do choose to, then pound is plenty, wrote Mrs McLaughlan.ldquoThis is about teaching the children about the spirit of giving and kindness, not about raising record breaking amounts.Parent to seven-year-old pupil Sofia, Linsey Milloy posted the letter to Facebook where it has been shared thousands of times.ldquoI was really touched by the generosity of Mrs McLaughlan, the -year-old told the Press Association.ldquoI think this shows everyone the true spirit of Christmas and am proud that my daughterrsquos class will be part of this.ldquoDoing all of this gives them great experience in social learning and itrsquos an excellent example to set to our children.Mrs McLaughlan said in the letter she had been overwhelmed by the ldquokind and thoughtful gts given to her by her pupils last year, which included chocolates, jewellery, and bath products.ldquoThe staff at Newark Primary are incredibly nurturing and work hard to support the local community, Mrs McLaughlan told the Press Association.ldquoThis year we are not swapping Secret Santa gts or cards, but sharing the money between three dferent charities: Rosiersquos Rascals, Inverclyde Foodbank and Compassionate Inverclyde, and we are asking for a food donation for the food bank on entrance to our Christmas fair.ldquoI work in a fantastic community with many unsung heroes. I would love the result of this to be that lots of charities benefit, the true spirit of Christmas is shared, and teacher presents become a thing of the past.ldquoThere are teachers in my school who donate to the foodbank with every weekly shop and also volunteer. They really are the people who need the recognition.The i Project, who run Inverclyde Foodbank, recently shared a video to social media explaining it had been unable to open due to a shortage of food on its shelves, an issue they explained is now a ldquoweekly occurrence.The video called for help with the incoming high demand of winter and Christmas.URGENT APPEALCan you help The i Project this Christmas!Please watch the following video message.See below for the links to sign up for supermarket collections either Greenock, Port Glasgow or both!Greenock Collection :https:www.signupgenius go AAAAAAFD-inverclydePort Glasgow Collection :https:www.signupgenius go AAAAAAFD-inverclydeCrowdfunder Link for donationshttps:www.crowdfunder the-i-project-at-christmasPosted by The i Project on Wednesday, November , ldquoMy daughter and the rest of her class are really keen to help with this, said Mrs Milloy.ldquoTo meother people followed suit with Mrs McLaughlan this would help greatly.ldquoNot only does it help those in need of assistance from the food bank, it also take financial pressure ofparents.ldquoI guess yoursquoll see it in every schools where some of the presents given to teachers are just taken too far and may make other pupils feel that their gts are inadequate.ldquoBy gting a couple of pounds in an anonymous envelope or even handing an empty envelope there is no judgment either way.

title: hs2-rail-chief-expects-sack-within-days
story: Sir Terry Morgan told the BBC there was disappointment at Westminster about delays affecting Londonrsquos poundbn Crossrail project, which he also chairs.It follows a report in The Financial Timesthat Prime Minister Theresa May is poised to sack Sir Terry, who started work at HS in August.He is expected to leave both jobs within weeks after a series of recent disclosures about problems at both projects raised doubts about his performance, according to the FT.ldquoHS is more than a railway, itrsquos an opportunity to regenerate and rebalance our economy. ndash Sir Terry Morgan, Chair, HS Ltd #HSEGC #HSontrack pic YjWWlLAdmdash HS LtdNovember , Sir Terry told Radio rsquos PM: ldquoI did get confirmation late yesterday afternoon that thatwas a leak, as far as Irsquom concerned.ldquoIrsquom expecting that to be confirmed more formally in the next few days.Asked why he thought he was being forced out, Sir Terry said: ldquoI can only but assume, because Irsquove not yet been told, that because HS is such a critically important programme and with the sense of disappointment around the performance of Crossrail that it was considered to be too risky for a programme like HS to continue in my role as chairman.Sir Terry was hailed as ldquoworld-class when he was appointed to the HS project by Transport Secretary Chris Grayling.News of his imminent departure has prompted fears of potential cuts to infrastructure spending from unions and criticism from the Stop HS Campaign who branded HS as ldquoa mess.Stop HS campaign manager Joe Rukin said: ldquoThe bottom line is that HS is a mess, itrsquos always been a mess, and imagining that this is the fault of a man who has only been in charge for four months is a delusional attempt by politicians to absolve themselves of the reality that it is their lack of scrutiny and objectivity that is responsible for HS being a disaster.Reacting to the earlier reports, unions warned of cuts to spending on rail projects.Manuel Cortes, leader of the Transport Salaried Staffs Association, said: ldquoMy big fear is that blaming lsquospiralling costsrsquo, is Tory code for more infrastructure cuts to come.ldquoIt was always nuts to have one person responsible for heading up both these enormous infrastructure projects. More so now that both are not on target.#Crossrail Chairman Sir Terry Morgan marks another huge milestone for the Crossrail project with install of @Elizabethline track complete # pic WoSdDsTjumdash Crossrail ProjectSeptember , Sir Terry has been chairman on the Crossrail project since June .It was announced on August  that the capitalrsquos new east-west railway will open in autumn  rather than December this year to complete infrastructure and testing.The projectrsquos budget was increased from pound. billion to pound. billion in July due to ldquocost pressures. It is being predominantly funded by Transport for Londonand the Government.In October, it was announced both TfL and the Department for Transport had commissioned an independent review of Crossrailrsquos governance and a separate review of its finance and commercial position.Sir Terry told the BBC there had been some ldquounfortunate comment about who knew what and when about whether the Crossrail project was running late.ldquoIrsquom very confident that Crossrail behaved properly, he said, claiming he told TfL and Mayor of London Sadiq Khan on July  the programme could not be delivered this year.A mayoral spokesman said:ldquoThe mayor considers it a damning indictment of Crossrail governance that the Mayor and TfL had to commission an independent report to tell them the true scale of the delays to the project.ldquoThis is the kind of crucial information that really should have come from the chairman, but didnrsquot.ldquoThe mayor has been clear that he discussed rising cost and schedule pressures with Crossrail Ltd over the summer, including looking at the implicationsthese issues werenrsquot resolved.ldquoAt the meeting at the end of July it was clear that the opening date was at high risk of being missed but it was not until the end of August that the mayor, TfL and the DfT were told that the opening of the central section would definitely be delayed until Autumn  ndash something the mayor has not hidden his anger and disappointment about.A DfT spokesman said the department did not comment on ldquopersonnel matters, but added in a statement: ldquoWe can confirm that the Crossrail board took the decision to delay the opening on Wednesday August  and informed the Secretary of State of that decision on August .

title: g20-leaders-make-trade-agreement
story: Applause rose up in the hall on Saturday as the leaders signed off on a final statement at the end of a two-day summit.The statement acknowledges flaws in the world trading system and calls for reforming the World Trade Organisationndash but does not mention protectionism because negotiators said the US had resisted that.The statement says  of the members reiterated their commitment to the Paris climate accord but the US reiterates its decision to withdraw.The non-binding agreement was reached after dficult all-night talks by diplomats.The US had been the main holdout on nearly every issue, officials previously said, as US President Donald Trump has criticised the WTO and taken aggressive trade policies targeting China and the EU."As members of the #G, we have tried to push for a global governance that is fairer, more prosperous and more inclusive" Pedro Saacutenchez, Spanish Prime Minister.mdash G Argentina ##December , China also pushed back in talks on steel, South Africa objected to language on trade, Australia did not want the statement to be too soft on migration and Turkey worried it would push too far on climate change, according to the officials.According to European officials, the US negotiator said too much talk about migration would have been a ldquodeal-breaker for Mr Trump.This led to them coming up with ldquominimalist language that acknowledges growing migrant flows and the importance of shared efforts to support refugees and solve the problems that drive them to flee.The statement also shows a commitment to a ldquorules-based international order, despite Mr Trumprsquos rejection of many of those rules.ldquoThere were moments when we thought all was lost, one European official said, ldquomoments when we spent two hours on one sentence.Perhaps surprisingly, one country seen as particularly constructive was Russia, the officials added.Despite tensions over its military actions on Ukraine and political interference abroad, Russia supports international efforts on trade and climate.While a statement is not legally enforceable, the Europeans see it as proof the G is still relevant and multilateralism still works.German Chancellor Angela Merkel said: ldquoEveryone agrees that the WTO should be reformed. This is an important agreement.ldquoWe will send a clear signal mdash in any case, most of us mdash for the success of global climate talks starting in Poland on Sunday, Ms Merkel added.Her spokesman said that during a meeting with Russian President Vladimir Putin, she also voiced concern about rising tensions in the Kerch Strait off Crimea and pushed for ldquofreedom of shipping into the Sea of Azov.Last weekend, Russia seized three Ukrainian naval vessels and their crews in an incident escalating a tug-of-war that began in  when Russia annexed Ukrainersquos Crimean Peninsula and supported separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine.Germany and France have sought to mediate between Russia and Ukraine, and spokesman Steffen Seibert said Ms Merkel and Mr Putin agreed the four countries should hold further talks at the ldquoadviser level.Ms Merkel also said she hopes a meeting between the US and Chinese leaders will help resolve trade tensions between the two countries.Mr Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping are due to meet on the sidelines of the summit in Buenos Aires.Ms Merkel told reporters it is important the talks ldquohopefully bring solutions, because all of us see that we are affected indirectly when Chinese-American economic relations are not as frictionless as a world order requires.The isions among the worldrsquos leading economies were evident from the moment Argentinarsquos president opened the summit Friday with a call for international cooperation to solve the planetrsquos problems.In closing remarks, summit host and Argentine President Mauricio Macri said the countries had overcome ldquoa number of challenges to reach the agreement.He said: ldquoWe have agreed on a statement that reflects the necessity of revitalising trade, of revitalising the WTO.ldquoWe raty the concern of everyone over climate change.The next G summit is to be held in Osaka, Japan, in June .

title: in-pictures-the-queen-with-george-hw-bush

title: indian-takeaway-near-glasgow-named-best-in-britain
story: Mushtaqs Restaurant, in Hamilton, walked away with the top accolade at a glittering ceremony in London.Over , VIP guests attended a gala dinner at the Grosvenor House Hotel to honour the winners at the Asian Curry Awards.FIRST LOOK: World-famous restaurant gears up for Glasgow opening after sudden closure of CarlucciosThe awards were co-hosted by BBC TV presenter Babita Sharma and Tommy Sandhu from the BBC Radio Asian Network.Mushtaqs, on Almada Street, is officially the biggest takeaway operation and was featured on BBCrsquos Best of British Takeaways.Mushtaqs in HamiltonHead chef Ajmal Mushtaq was crowned Scotlandrsquos Chef of the Year at the Food Awards Scotland in August last year where he beat off competition from the best fine dining and Michelin trained chefs in the country.He said: ldquoIt was overwhelming when it was announced that we had won the title of being the Best Takeaway in Britain.:City Centre basement bar shuts its doors to customers before ChristmasldquoThis is great news for Hamilton and we are just honoured to have put Hamilton on the culinary map once again.ldquoWe are really grateful for the love and support we have received from the people of Hamilton ndash they are the best.:Mystery as massive Glasgow City Centre BBQ restaurant suddenly shutsldquoMy wonderful team deserve this great award.There is an incredible amount of hard work, skill and quality control that goes into making every meal the very best it can be and for Mushtaqs to be recognised at the highest level was a great achievement.Best Maicirctre Drsquo went to Mohammed Sultan of Charcoals on Renfield Street.

title: dolph-lundgren-on-childhood-grace-jones-stardom-and-what-makes-a-man
story: ldquoI just want someone I can hold on toI want muscles. ndash Singer Diana RossThe night before we talk, Dolph Lundgren tells me, he appeared on a Swedish TV show. ldquoOne of those late-night talks shows where they always throw a curveball at the guests, he explains.ldquoI was sitting there in my suit talking about stuff and the guy starts talking about fitness. And he pulled out these two chin bars onto the stage in front of the audience and said: lsquoWersquore going to do a chin contest.rsquoldquoSo, there I am ending up doing chins to prove myself.He pauses, thinks about that and then adds: ldquoIt wasnrsquot like solving dferential equations.True, but how did you do anyway Dolph  ldquoI did OK, actually. They cut out after . Still,I hadnrsquot been working out it would have been kind of embarrassing not to be able to do one.It is, I accept, more than possible that you havenrsquot thought about Dolph Lundgren since the s. Back in the day he was the Russian villain Ivan Drago in the Rocky movies and appeared in a loin cloth and not much  in the live-actionversion of He-Man.But that was then. Apart from the odd appearance in an Expendables sequel or two , his IMDB listing is full of what we used to call straight-to-video titles such as Puncture Wounds, Silent Trigger and Sharknado : Global Swarming.And yet suddenly Lundgren is back in fashion, with roles in two full-on, proper Hollywood movies. Right now, hersquos back in cinemas as an older Ivan Drago in the latest Rocky iteration, Creed . And next month he turns up as King Nereus in the new underwater superhero movie Aquaman next month.He wasnrsquot sure about taking a role in the former. ldquoI didnrsquot want to mess with that character, he says. ldquoItrsquos a bit of an iconic character and I did it many many years ago.ldquoBut the script turned out to be very good and it uses how Irsquove aged and how the franchise has changed and I thought it was a good marriage.And the result is very dferent from the original movies. ldquoYes it is. Both films are directed by young African-American directors. So, Itrsquos more more urban, itrsquos younger itrsquos very modern, very character driven. I like that.With these roles, it feels, he admits, like hersquos been given another chance. ldquoIrsquove done a lot of work on myself and Irsquom trying to put out a lot of good energy out into the universe. And yeah, maybe the energy is bouncing back now, and I get a chance to express myself a little bit. Still in the action adventure realm, but with good directors and more interesting characters.ldquoIt feels exciting. It could be the beginning of a nice second act.Lundgren is  now. He lives in Los Angeles these days. That might not surprise you given the way he talks. But hersquos smarter ndash intellectually and emotionally ndash than his image might suggest.He has just been on a trip to London to take his youngest daughter to boarding school there. But when we talk he is still in Sweden, his homeland. A good place, perhaps, for him to take stock of the first act of his le. The days growing up under the shadow of an abusive father, his wild days with Grace Jones and an unexpected movie stardom that was not what he had been planning. Fame, fatherhood, orce, therapy. Theyrsquore all part of the story.Talking about all of this Lundgren makes for entertaining, wryly amusing company. He doesnrsquot shy away from the damage wrought on him and by him, but he has a kind of Calornian hippy laissez faire attitude to it all now.It is fair to say that, back when he first became a star, some of us never really looked beyond the muscles. To be honest, it was something of a revelation to me to read Grace Jonesrsquos autobiography and learn that before they met Lundgren had a degree and a masterrsquos in chemical engineering and had won a Fulbright scholarship to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in Boston. A road not taken in the end.Therersquos a mind there that has been ignored by most of us. ldquoHah, yeah, it gets ignored a lot, he laughs.ldquoI think I have suffered from that inner confusion, he adds. ldquoDid I do the right thing  Why do people look at me in a certain way  And then, of course, you look at Ivan Drago. As a character hersquos a guy in red shorts who beats people up. You look at He-Man. His outfit is the size of a stamp. He carries a huge sword and he chops people up. I understand why people look at me in a certain way.ldquoI look back now at what I looked like when I was that age and Irsquom a little bit amazed. Wow, I look unreal. And this was before Photoshop.ldquoPeople couldnrsquot imagine that guy was a Fulbright scholar and I understand. I couldnrsquot have imagined it either.Who was that young science student  A boy whose le had been shaped by his father in many ways.Karl Johan Hugo Lundgren was an engineer who had also spent time in the military. You can see the influence of the father on the sonrsquos choices. Perhaps in the circumstances that is not a surprise.ldquoHe was a very strong man. He was a big guy. He was an officer and a gentleman in some ways, Lundgren says. ldquoHe was a snappy dresser. He was a scholar.ldquoAnd he also had a really dark side.The stain of that is something Lundgren himself has been dealing with all his le. Dealing with mental and physical abuse.ldquoWhen he got older, when the dark forces came, he took it out on me and my mom. He beat me a lot. And my mom too.He understands things more now, he says. His father had been abused as a child himself. ldquoAs a young boy you try to handle that. I had a lot of trauma. I still have some.The teenage Lundgren channelled some of his rage into boxing and martial arts and later acting. ldquoBut like somebody said, you hijack the emotion and you take it and use it. I donrsquot react from that place, which I did a lot in the past.Well, yes. The fact is that his fatherrsquos violence shaped much of his le for years, decades even. ldquoI was angry with him and I had plans to take revenge physically on him, Lundgren admits. ldquoBut I never carried those through because it just didnrsquot make any sense and by the time I was a martial artist I had other values of respect and a little more wisdom when it came to violence.ldquoI forgave him early on and I still forgive him, and I meditate for what he did.He goes off at a tangent for a moment. ldquoI think when you look at somebody who bumps into you or cuts you off in LA traffic itrsquos easy to say lsquohey, F you, man.rsquoldquoYou think you want to kill that person. You donrsquot even know them.ldquoAnd then, when I take a deep breath, I realise: lsquoHang on a second, thatrsquos why we have wars, thatrsquos why young men and young women are being blown to pieces all over the place because people donrsquot take time and take a breath and say: lsquowell, maybe it wasnrsquot that guyrsquos fault. Maybe he had a bad day. And he wasnrsquot doing it to me. It wasnrsquot personal.He is candid when he talks about the impact his fatherrsquos behaviour had on his own when he himself became a father with his now ex-we Anette Qviberg. Because what does it mean when an abusive man is your paternal role model ldquoYeah, it was dficult for me. Luckily, I had two daughters. Therersquos no sense of competition. But, yeah, I didnrsquot handle it well. I mean. I was always loving to them. I never beat them or anything.ldquoBut I did abuse myself. I was drinking too much. I was absent a lot early on in their upbringing and it was because I was dealing with my own demons.ldquoBut at some point, about  years ago I started doing therapy and I started meditating I became wiser about what had happened, and I went back to them and I spoke to them and also my ex-we and I asked for forgiveness. I told them about my dad and they started crying.ldquoNow they understand that, yes, a big strong guy like their dad can make mistakes too. You can ask for forgiveness for things yoursquove done.Of course, before Lundgren even became a father you also need to factor in fame and success into the mix. Unexpected fame it must be said. ldquoI donrsquot know why it happened that quickly, but it did.Lundgren met Grace Jones in Australia and soon was accompanying her to Studio , hanging out with Andy Warhol and trying out for a role in the James Bond movie A View to a Kill because his girlfriend already had a role in it. Next thing he knew he was cast in Rocky IV as Ivan ldquoI must break you Drago.ldquoSomebody said: lsquoYou got famous overnight.rsquo And I said lsquoNo, I got famous in  minutes. The movie lasted  minutes. When I walked in nobody cared about me. They were taking pictures of Grace Jones and trying to get me out of the way, so I wouldnrsquot block the view.ldquoAnd then as I was coming out people were taking pictures of me and it took me years to get over that. Itrsquos not like Irsquod been an actor waiting tables dreaming of success. Irsquod been at MIT in Boston a year and a half before that deciding to give up my scholarship.At the time his le was one of sex, drugs and disco in the days before Aids started cutting swathes through the people he knew. Hersquos talked before of Jonesrsquos appetites: for drugs and group sex. The partying lestyle led to inevitable clashes with Sylvester Stallone who was acting and directing Rocky IV and wanted his co-star to turn up early and bright-eyed .Lundgren was being pulled in two directions and in the end his relationship with Jones was pulled apart.That said, Jones has nothing but good things to say about Lundgren in her  memoir. In fact, therersquos a line in it, I remind him, where she writes: ldquoI would say Dolph saved my le.ldquoShit, really  I havenrsquot read it. Wow. Thatrsquos beautul, he says. ldquoYou know, I didnrsquot think I was in it.ldquoWhy did I save her le  Well, I know what happened was she met this young man, a young student karate fighter in Australia, and two years later he was a movie star. I donrsquot know why it happened so quickly, but it did. It put a lot of strain on the relationship and we broke up a year later.ldquoI think she suffered a lot for that. And I didnrsquot know how to save it. I wasnrsquot smart enough and it fell apart and at that point she went through a lot of problems. And I did help her a few times when she was in trouble.These days Dolph Lundgren might start the day with meditation and some cardio before breakfast and maybe weights later in the day. Hersquos older now. He had hip surgery in June and hersquos doing physio for that too.ldquoI donrsquot push myself physically the way I used to do. Apart from that I try to eat every four hours, so I donrsquot snack too much. Ifrsquo Irsquom filming Irsquom on set,not I try to chill out with my two daughters.I wonder what his definition of masculinity is now  What, Dolph, should a man be  ldquoA man  Oh boy. Well, I think itrsquos a number of things. Hersquos certainly an inidual who has to be strong and protective and caring about the people around him and at the same time he has to be loving and understanding and compassionate and, I think, forgiving. Otherwise, you canrsquot forgive other people. You end up fighting all the time and thatrsquos dangerous for yourself and for the world.And yet the movies ndash and letrsquos be honest, his movies ndash prefer the fighting to the forgiving. ldquoYeah, yoursquore right. A lot of films Irsquove been in portray violence and revenge in a sort of cartoonish way where itrsquos portrayed as something you have to do and there are no consequences to it. No negative consequences.ldquoBut both of the films Irsquove got coming out this year, Aquaman and Creed  Irsquove been lucky. I was fortunate enough to play characters who are dealing with that situation, with that struggle within. Both Drago and the king I play in Aquaman are asking: lsquoShould I forgive  Should I break the cycle of violence rsquo And I think both characters make the right choice.ldquoI tried to hone in on that part of the characters because thatrsquos how I look at le now.Creed  is in cinemas now. Aquaman goes on general release on December .

title: retire-from-what-why-paul-mccartney-keeps-on-going
story: In the last  months, Elton John, Ozzy Osbourne, Neil Diamond, Kiss and the grizzled remnants of Lynyrd Skynyrd have announced end-of-the-road tours. Paul Simon has already embraced the sound of silence with a final show in September in New York while fellow Sixties luminary Joan Baez is also packing away the touring set list for good.But for all those happy to exit stage left after decades of strutting vanity, there are still others who continue to rage against the dying of the light and the onset of their twilight years. Mick Jagger, Keith Richards, Robert Plant, Neil Young and Bob Dylan are still rocking well into their eighth decade, having long ago sold their souls for rock lsquonrsquo roll in some kind of Faustian pact.Itrsquos hard to imagine James Paul McCartney making a deal with the devil to prolong a career that now stretches back  years to the day he first met a fellow teenager called John Lennon on hallowed ground at a church fete in Liverpool. But a rummage around his attic for a Dorian-Gray type image might offer up a clue.On Friday, December , the former Beatle brings his Freshen Up tour to Glasgowrsquos SSE Hydro, the latest staging post of a -show itinerary that takes in America, Japan and Europe. By the time it reaches its climax next June in Phoenix, McCartney will have turned .A born performer, the musician has never met a stage he didnrsquot like. Still driven by a relentless work ethic, he steadfastly refuses to surrender to the notion that it might be time to finally hang up his famous Hofner bass and swap the le of a pensioner rock star for a rocking chair. Itrsquos a subject that occasionally rankles. He prefers instead to still consider music more as a hobby than anything approaching the nine-to-five.ldquoI was talking to Willie Nelson, about this whole retiring thing, because hes older than I am, even, he said. ldquoAnd he says, Retire from what  And I think that just says it. Retire from what The only concession to the march of time has been to finally let the grey in his hair grow out. Other than that, itrsquos business as usual and business this year has reaped a particularly bountul harvest. A media blitz for Egypt Station, his th solo album, was rewarded with impressive reviews and brought him his first American Number One in  years.And it was followed by the th anniversary reboot in November of the Beatlesrsquo White Album, which again showcased the imperishable legacy of his old compadres and the unbreakable chains of his ever present past.His Carpool Karaoke with James Corden saw him visiting childhood haunts in Liverpool and introduced him to an entirely new audience of millennials. According to YouTube, the footage has been seen by million people.In September he took over New Yorkrsquos Grand Central Station for a surprise show that literally did stop the traffic. And now here he is hitting the boards once again, maintaining the kind of pace a man half his age would do well to muster.Rumours persist of a headline-grabbing appearance at Glastonbury next year. His Scottish gig comes  years after the Beatles first played in Glasgow at the Odeon and his first since Hampden in , but oddly it will be only his ninth concert appearance overall in a city he once name-checked in the song Helen Wheels.McCartney has been famous at an unimaginable level longer than nearly anyone  alive. To put an astonishing le into context, he wrote Yesterday, the worldrsquos most covered song, in  when he was just  years of age. He was a Fab Fab Four millionaire by the time he was  at a time when the Treasury was trousering  old pennies from every pound he earned and is today unchallenged as the worldrsquos richest musician with a fortune estimated to be not far south of a billion pounds.The legacy of his songwriting alliance with Lennon continues to shimmer down the decades Deezer last week revealed more people under the age of  currently stream Beatles tracks than those who would have been around in their Sixties pomp. And the legacy of his prodigious post-Beatles output with Wings and his solo output garners more plaudits as the years tick down.There have, though, been plenty of tears in the rain. He was scarred by the death of his mum Mary ndash the hymn-like subject of Let It Be - from breast cancer when he was just . He slipped into a post-Beatles funk at his Argyle farm on the Mull of Kintyre before being pulled out of the blackness by his we Linda.Lennonrsquos dreadful assassination at the hands of a deranged fan in  saw McCartney retreat to the margins ndash he turned his back on touring for nine years. His -year marriage to Linda was tragically ended by cancer in  before the same illness claimed the le of fellow Beatle George Harrison three years later.Wersquoll gloss over the mis-step of his subsequent marriage to the former model Heather Mills and the toxic ndash and expensive - aftermath that was played out so dramatically in the orce courts. Today, McCartney is happily married to third we Nancy Shevell, a publicity-shy American who provides the reassuring comfort blanket for a man who has never been without a female companion since the age of .He takes enormous pride in his four children ndash the youngest from his marriage to Mills - and an extended family that also includes eight grandchildren. Yet there remains a sense that McCartney has been underestimated by history, a man who, despite his undoubted musical genius, is in his own way as insecure and vulnerable as Lennon was his seeming total opposite.Music continues to nurture and nourish his le. But his most recent work has caught a man looking wistfully in the mirror and perhaps reading the runes of his own mortality. And this sombre self-examination is played out in the first track on his latest album, his voice frail and aged. On ldquoYesterday, he sounded like a wounded youth. On ldquoI Donrsquot Know, he naturally sounds like an older man, his vocals now able to convey sadness not as an effect but as a fact.His voice was once one of musicrsquos most powerful instruments, as potent in its own way as Jimmy Pagersquos guitar or Clarence Clemonsrsquo saxophone. But the debacle of his sub-par performances at the closing ceremony for the  Olympics and the Queenrsquos Diamond Jubilee the same year handed critics a gilt-edged cudgel. The court of public opinion also delivered a damning verdict.McCartneyrsquos response was simply to circle the wagons behind the band that has been the mainstay of his live shows for almost  years and carry on regardless. The high notes are unquestionably harder to hit but he remains dedicated to his craft, in and outside the studio.His  collaboration with Kanye West and Rihanna on the song FourFiveSeconds may have mortied traditional fans but it gained him kudos with a new audience. These days more than any other McCartney seems to take shelter in the solace of live shows, asthe stage still offers an escape route from lersquos problems. On another Egypt Station track, he wistfully talks about having been ldquobroken in so many places, held together by a sea of faces.Which brings us to an inevitable question  Is this tour the full stop on Paul McCartneyrsquos performing career and will Decemberrsquos show at the Hydro mark his farewell to his Scottish fans  Wersquove been here before, of course. Final show. Final encore. Final bow.But this time feels like the end of a long and winding road, especially given the eight years that have elapsed since his last Scottish concert. Even for rock stars, the fat lady eventually has to have the final word. Yesterday really did come suddenly.Paul McCartney plays the SSE Hydro in Glasgow on December

title: ron-mackenna-reviews-lazord-syrian-street-food-glasgow
story: Howard StreetGlasgow  Opening hours: til late seven daysTONIGHT itrsquos quite clear that all the young dudes are carrying the news but exactly what language itrsquos in I canrsquot quite make out. Irsquoll only be told that when I eventually make it to the long, low metal-topped counter through a sardine can of sprawling, leaning, chatting, arm-on-each-otherrsquos-shoulders customers.Then while ordering Irsquoll ask the man where all these people are originally from and hersquoll say mainly Syria, but all over really, and theyrsquore talking Arabic.Ours will be a brief conversation because hersquos busy and because all the time I am being gently pushed, slightly bumped, harmlessly nudged back down the counter by the surge of clippered-side-shed hairstyles with gelled-back qufs.My slow journey there had been enhanced though, by watching pirouetting chickens dance, bubble and brown on burners so hot I can feel them pleasantly toast my face on this bitterly cold November night.Its not what I came in for but I have to have me some of that chicken. Served with salad, the famous Muhammara sauce from Aleppo, Saj bread and rice please.ldquoA least  minutes til theyrsquore ready mate," says the man switching to Glaswegian. I shake my head at the prospect of another wait and order instead the Arabic Shawarma Wrap at just over pound.What I donrsquot realise is that all the young dudes havenrsquot got their food yet and by the time theyrsquove got theirs and Irsquove got mine that rotisserie chicken will be completely ready. So I will have one of them too.Now. Of all the wonderful things that immigrants bring and have brought and will hopefully continue to bring to this city over the years, their food has surely got to rank super high up there. Look about. Itrsquos everywhere.And when you can step off a pavement in downtown Glasgow, just round the corner from St Enoch Square, and culturally anyway yoursquove stumbled into Syria from a better time and its going like a fair, well it livens up an otherwise dull Tuesday night doesnrsquot it I know what yoursquore thinking. Yoursquore thinking: a shawarma  I thought that too. Until I got mine. Juicy chicken straight from the grill, chopped, doused in sauce, wrapped tightly in the flatbread they make freshly themselves in here then the whole thing placed on another grill. And big old iron weights put on top of it. To flatten it down. To deliciously crisp that flatbread up.Itrsquos then sliced across the grain. Into surprisingly elegant finger-size bites. And served with Syrian Garlic Cream, more chilli sauce, and those sour and salty pickles that they make themselves. Outstanding.On those pickles by the way: try the Pickled Scottish Turnip. Crikey, who knew  Most dudes are having chips with their shawarmas tonight, but this dudersquos having that buttery rice, full of the flavour of cardamom.And the chicken  As good as it looked. Just-cooked, moist and sweetly tender. I wont eat it in here but take it home for the family to try, dipping torn off pieces of the Saj bread and chicken into that deep, dense Muhammara of peppers, walnuts, chilli and possibly even pomegranate.It would have been easy to walk past Lazord on a night like this without even noticing it. It looks like any one of the scores of kebab shops in the city centre. They keep the shutter down too on the side with two big tables.I probably wouldnrsquot have come in at allI hadnrsquot had a number of emails suggesting I brave the steady rush. Even then itrsquos hard to get a seat at one of the tables and simple, utilitarian and not hugely comfortable when I do.But still better to experience the Arabic Shawarama on site - to understand the crispness of the fresh flatbread, its all round juicyness. That crispness goes when its placed in a takeaway box.I know all this because of course Irsquove now been more than once. And will be back again. And probably again.Menu: Whole rotisserie chicken with that famous Aleppo Muhammara and Saj bread and those Arabic Shawarmas. What  do you need  Service: Worth the wait. Can feel like every man for himself in the surge to get served but persevere andthe counter staff get a minute theyrsquore pleasant, friendly and immensely proud of what they do. Atmosphere: Itrsquos a buzzing kebab shop with just two biggish tables, rotating chickens, flaring burners and faststreet food. I liked it. Price: Factor in the care they take over preparation and at pound for an Arabic Shawarma meal, pound for the whole chicken with Muhammara and Saj,   doesnrsquot do it justice. Food: Come for the elegant Arabic Shawarma with its dainty sections, crisped up deliciousness, juicy meats and carefully made pride. Total:

title: tom-gordon-brexits-unintended-consequences-for-may-and-sturgeon
story: A campaign to take back control has yielded a plan that cedes more to Brussels instead. After being promised wealth on buses, we face hardship on stilts. And after hammering warnings of No Deal to get her own way, Theresa May has invalidated No Deal by mistake.In the last week, wersquove seen the UK Government warning No Deal could lop % off GDP by  relative to our current economic trajectory. Security minister Ben Wallace said No Deal could put the country at greater risk of crime and terrorism. And Scottish Secretary David Mundell doubled down on his claim that No Deal would be ldquocatastrophic for the Union.So dire have been the worst-case scenarios that MPs have united to block No Deal. The apocalypse appears to have been cancelled.Mrs May also made the ldquonational interest her yardstick on Brexit. But in what circumstances would the national interest be best served by No Deal  How could she argue it would be in the national interest to enter recession, choke the ports, disrupt the food supply chain, upend industry, risk social unrest, and jeopardise her precious Union, as her own cabinet has warned She has killed off her bogeyman. Instead of No Deal warnings making it more likely MPs will back her deal, it has made them more likely to reject it, as they no longer feel a chaotic exit hanging over them.They now reckon they have more space to explore other options - a softer Norway-style Brexit with single market and customs union membership is the current favourite, or a Peoplersquos Vote, the option increasingly favoured by Labour.Some politicians point out that, although Mrs May and the EU say the current deal is the only one on offer, it is more accurate to say it is the only negotiated deal. That doesnrsquot mean itrsquos the only option. Off-the-shelf plans, such as EFTA membership, are out there too.Nicola Sturgeon always said it was a ldquo choice between Mrs Mayrsquos deal and No Deal, and Mrs May and cabinet have proved it. Brexit is rich with unintended consequences.Another unintended consequence applies to Ms Sturgeon. The First Minister recently announced her MPs would vote in favour of a Peoplersquos Votegiven the chance. It was not a universally popular idea.Pete Wishart, the longest serving SNP MP, warned it could work against the independence cause, setting a precedent that could see Unionists demand a re-run of a referendum ending in a Yes vote.Alex Salmond raised the same point on his TV show last month.Irsquom not sure about this argument. The SNP conceded the principle that referendums can be rerun as soon as it lost the  vote. ldquoThe dream shall never die, as Mr Salmond said in his resignation. Then Ms Sturgeon called a second referendum in March  over Brexit to reverse the No vote.The argument seems more about timing than principle about how long to wait before voters will put up with another referendum.But there is a more pressing aspect to Ms Sturgeon supporting a Peoplersquos Vote. If her MPs back it, they will be voting against another independence referendum. Not directly, of course. But the former would surely preclude the latter.Imagine the Prime Minister is defeated on December  and the upshot, after much wailing and gnashing of dentistry, is that MPs decide to palm the mess off onto you and me. Sorry, I mean trust the people to decide what to do next. This would not be a speedy process.The EU would have to agree to extend the Article  process by a year or more to put Brexit on ice. Another referendum means a bespoke Bill going through Westminster. The last one took seven months. A second referendum Bill would be resisted at every turn by apoplectic Brexiteers. There would be a furious debate about what would be on the ballot paper.Would it be a choice between Leave and Remain again  Or a multiple choice  Perhaps the UK governmentrsquos deal versus a dferent deal , staying in the EU or a sod-it No Deal.If it was first-past-the-post, the winner would almost certainly get less than the % that gave Leave victory in . Imagine the stink that would cause. If it was decided by proportional representation, transfers might see most peoplersquos second choice come out on top. That doesnrsquot sound like a recipe for clarity and contentment either.The Electoral Commission would need weeks to mull it over. There would then be another four months of campaigning, and a potentially long and messy aftermath.The process could be doubly confused by a Tory leadership contest and a winner shting the government position mid-stream.This would all take time, time Ms Sturgeon doesnrsquot haveshe wants a second referendum before her ldquocast-iron mandate runs out in .As Irsquove written before, the First Minister has to make a call on Indyref by mid-it is happen in this parliament, because of legislation and campaign time. Butthere was a second EU vote she would have to wait till that was over, and by then it would be too late.She canrsquot have two referendums running at once. That would be a dogrsquos dinner. But nor can she have one after the other because therersquos not enough time for both by .The Scottish Tories claimed this week that Ms Sturgeon is backing a Peoplersquos Vote to cause chaos and boost the prospects of the Yes movement. But Irsquod say a Peoplersquos Vote is more likely to stall the Yes movement, at least for a few years.Faced with this choice between two referendums, I wonder how SNP MPs will vote in the end.

title: prestwick-under-pressure-after-advertising-jobs-below-real-living-wage
story: But five years on, Glasgow Prestwick Airport is under fresh pressure after it emerged it is still advertising jobs which fail to pay the real living wage, despite Nicola Sturgeon urging all employers to do so.Opponents have now accused Ms Sturgeon of ldquorank hypocrisy after she criticised the Ministry of Defence for paying more than  civilian staff less than the living wage during First Ministerrsquos Questions on Thursday.She said: ldquoThe MoD and all Government agencies should pay the real living wage. The Scottish Government is a real living wage employer.Earlier this week, SNP MSP Gordon Macdonald said it was a ldquodisgrace that hard-working staff are being ripped off by penny-pinching bosses at the MoD.This is despite a job description which insists they ldquomust be available around the clock to cover all flight operations and have ldquototal flexibility, as well as being prepared to guard VIP or military aircraft in all weathers.It says the work is "physically challenging", with shts starting as "early as  and as late as ".Scottish Labourrsquos Colin Smyth said the low salaries ndash which have previously seen staff threaten strike action ndash were ldquounacceptable.He said: ldquoPrestwick Airport is owned by the SNP Government and it should ensure it pays a fair wage for a decent dayrsquos work.ldquoIt is rank hypocrisy for Nicola Sturgeon to say UK Government agencies should pay the living wage when it has failed to ensure Prestwick Airport does.ldquoNo one underestimates the huge financial crisis facing the airport, but the Government have provided more than pound million in loans to Prestwick so it is deeply disappointing that the few thousand pounds needed to pay the real living wage hasnrsquot been found.He also raised concerns over the airport cutting back on policing at a time when it is hosting an increasing number of military aircraft, adding: "The SNP Government must assure the public that the airport will be safely policed.Leaked board minutes from August  reveal police numbers at the facility were reduced in September this year.The document added: ldquoPolice Scotland will manage the implications of the reduction in  hour coverage.It comes as Prestwickrsquos accounts state it is ldquospecically targeting new military business as a key component of its future development activities. It is also a ldquoersionary airport capable of dealing with planes experiencing security risks.A police source said the reduction was likely down to low passenger numbers, adding: ldquoCops are not there to protect the premises ndash thatrsquos the role of security. They are there for protecting passengers.The Scottish Government bought the Ayrshire site in November . The airport has since been handed more than pound million in loans despite continuing to make losses.Its accounts say this funding will continue for the ldquoforeseeable, but turnover is increasing. Meanwhile, extra revenue has come from fuelling aircraft.This is ldquoprimarily due to military activities on the back of being awarded a contract in October  with the Defense Logistics Agency, a combat support agency in the United States Department of Defense.However both Edinburgh and Glasgow airports claim Prestwickrsquos public subsidy has ldquodistorted the market, and bosses previously admitted it would be forced to shutasked to repay its loans.A Scottish Government spokeswoman said Prestwick was operated at armrsquosndash but signalled unhappiness over its continued failure to pay the real living wage.She said: ldquoWhile this is a matter for Glasgow Prestwick Airport, we want it to continue to grow with a long-term future, and that includes taking its living wage responsibilities seriously.A spokeswoman for Prestwick said: ldquoGlasgow Prestwick Airport has made a commitment to pay our employees the Scottish living wage by April .ldquoPolice Scotland determine the required level of policing needed at Glasgow Prestwick Airport.Police did not respond to a request for comment.
